questions.text:
A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. A chest radiograph is obtained as part of the work-up and shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the structures represents the aortic arch?
questions.solution:
The cardiac silhouette refers to the heart’s outline as seen on frontal and lateral chest radiographs. The size and shape of the cardiac silhouette provide useful clues for underlying disease.

In the frontal view, the cardiac silhouette can be divided into right and left borders. The right border is formed by the right atrium. The superior vena cava can be seen at its upper margin and the inferior vena cava at its lower margin. The left border is formed by the left ventricle and left atrial appendage. The pulmonary artery extends superiorly. On top of the pulmonary artery is the aortic arch.

On the lateral view, the anterior border of the cardiac silhouette is formed by the right ventricle. The posterior border is formed by the left atrium (superiorly) and left ventricle (inferiorly).  



Image reproduced from Radiopedia  

Option Analysis

✅ Structure A  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Structure B  :
Incorrect: This structure is the left heart border, which is formed primarily by the left ventricle. Superiorly, it connects with the left atrial appendage.  
❌ Structure C  :
Incorrect: Structure C is the right heart border and is formed by primarily the right atrium. The superior portions of the right heart border are also formed by the superior vena cava.  
❌ Structure D  :
Incorrect: This labeled structure is the trachea.  
❌ Structure E  :
Incorrect: This labeled structure is the left main bronchus. It is formed by the division of trachea at the level of carina.

questions.text: A medical student is on her radiology rotation when the radiologist is asked to interpret a portable AP chest x-ray. While analyzing the x-ray, the radiologist begins discussing the anatomic significance of different findings on chest radiography.  Which of the following heart structures is outlined on the chest x-ray below?
questions.solution:
A standard anterior-posterior chest x-ray provides a plethora of information regarding anatomic structures of the heart. Notably, several structures make up the borders of the heart on standard chest radiography, including the right atrium, aortic arch, pulmonary artery, left auricle, and left ventricle. Derangements in these borders of the heart can aid in the diagnosis of underlying conditions (e.g. irregular aortic contour suggestive of aortic dissection). A specific finding known as the silhouette sign occurs when the normal heart borders are lost due to a pathological process in direct contact with the anatomic borders of the heart (e.g. pneumonia).  



Option Analysis

✅ Right atrium:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right ventricle:
Incorrect: The right ventricle does not comprise the borders of the heart on a standard chest x-ray, given its more anterior position in the thoracic cavity. 
❌ Left ventricle :
Incorrect: The left ventricle comprises the left lower portion of the heart border on a standard chest x-ray. 
❌ Aortic arch:
Incorrect: The aortic arch comprises the most superior portion of the left heart border. 
❌ Pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: The pulmonary artery can be visualized as inferior to the aortic arch on chest radiography.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a bar fight. Per emergency medical services, the patient sustained a stab wound to the right anterior chest. Prompt physical examination demonstrates a pocket knife lodged in the anterior chest wall. It is located in the parasternal space at the level of the fourth intercostal space. Given this patient's trauma mechanism, which of the following regions of the heart is at the most significant risk of injury?
questions.solution:
Cardiac injury secondary to penetrating trauma to the thorax is a leading cause of death due to urban violence (approximately 80% mortality rate). Understanding the anatomic locations of chambers in the heart can help predict the area of injury. Most penetrating trauma to the heart is to the right ventricle (43%) compared to the left ventricle (34%), owing to its anterior anatomic location. The atria are also less commonly injured, given their more posterior anatomic location and shielding via the sternum. Following injury, patients may exsanguinate into the pleural space if the cardiac lesion communicates freely with the pleural cavity, or they may suffer cardiac tamponade if the hemorrhage is contained within the pericardium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Right ventricle:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right atrium:
Incorrect: While the right atrium also lies anteriorly in the thorax, it is relatively protected by the sternum. Given this patient's mechanism of injury, the right ventricle is more susceptible to injury. 
❌ Left ventricle :
Incorrect: The left ventricle lies most posterior in the thorax, thus shielding it from anterior penetrating stab wounds. 
❌ Left atrium:
Incorrect: Like the left ventricle, the left atrium lies most posterior in the thorax, thus shielding it from anterior penetrating stab wounds. 
❌ Aortic outflow tract :
Incorrect: The aortic outflow tract is protected posteriorly in the thorax. Penetrating stab wounds are unlikely to injure this vessel.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the cardiologist for a routine visit. During this visit, the patient is diagnosed with arteriosclerosis. Which of the following best describes the systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, pulse pressure, and arterial compliance of this patient when compared to those of a healthy individual?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with arteriosclerosis. The condition is characterized by the hardening of the arterial walls. He will likely have elevated systolic blood pressure, unchanged diastolic blood pressure, elevated pulse pressure, and reduced arterial compliance.

Pulse pressure is defined as the difference between systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP). Pulse pressure is directly proportional to stroke volume and inversely proportional to arterial compliance. An increase in stroke volume means more blood is ejected from the heart, which would result in an increased SBP and pulse pressure. Similarly, a decrease in vascular compliance means the ejected blood is pushing against a stiff vascular wall, which would also increase SBP and pulse pressure.

These physiological parameters can be illustrated via some clinical scenarios. One example is arteriosclerosis, which leads to decreased arterial compliance. SBP will increase whereas DBP, which is determined by total peripheral resistance (provided chiefly by the arterioles), will remain largely unchanged. The end result is an increased pulse pressure. Another example is aortic stenosis. In this condition, narrowing of the aortic valve interferes with the ejection of blood from the left ventricle into the aorta and results in a decreased stroke volume. In turn, SBP and ultimately pulse pressure are decreased.
 

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Arteriosclerosis will lead to stiff blood vessels that have a difficult time expanding in response to changes in pressure. As a result, arterial compliance, which is defined as the change in volume divided by the change in pressure, will be decreased. Furthermore, diastolic blood pressure will be largely unchanged in patients with arteriosclerosis.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient was diagnosed with arteriosclerosis. While patients with arteriosclerosis will have elevated systolic blood pressure and reduced arterial compliance, their diastolic blood pressure will remain largely unchanged. Additionally, patients with arteriosclerosis will have an elevated systolic blood pressure since blood ejected by the heart is now pushing against a stiff vascular wall that has difficulty expanding. The combination of elevated systolic blood pressure and unchanged diastolic blood pressure will in turn result in elevated pulse pressure.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient was diagnosed with arteriosclerosis or hardening of the arterial walls. Patients with arteriosclerosis will have elevated systolic blood pressure since blood ejected by the heart is now pushing against a stiff vascular wall that has difficulty expanding. The combination of elevated systolic blood pressure and unchanged diastolic blood pressure will in turn result in elevated pulse pressure.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Arteriosclerosis will lead to stiff blood vessels that have a difficult time expanding in response to changes in pressure. As a result, arterial compliance, which is defined as the change in volume divided by the change in pressure, will be decreased. Furthermore, arteriosclerosis will result in an increased, not decreased, systolic blood pressure.

questions.text: A disease of the heart in elderly patients is being studied by a group of researchers. In the study, it was discovered that the sinoatrial (SA) cells in the SA node become fibrosed and are unable to generate action potentials. Which of the following is expected to happen as a result of this disease?

choices.text: Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at a lower firing rate than the SA node
Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at a higher firing rate than the SA node
Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at the same firing rate than the SA node
Myocytes in the atria and ventricles generate their own action potentials separately
Action potentials cannot be generated spontaneously

questions.solution:
The heart is unique because of its ability to generate its own electrical action potential. This is due to the presence of pacemaker cells which generate action potentials spontaneously and send the impulses to the heart myocytes, therefore contracting the heart.

The main pacemaker cells in the heart are found in the sinoatrial (SA) node located in the right atrium near the opening of the superior vena cava. These cells have the highest firing rate and the shortest action potential duration of all pacemaker cells, allowing them to depolarize very fast after each action potential. The rate of depolarization determines the heart rate. Because of their highest firing rate and shortest action potential, these cells usually take over, generating the action potential in the heart.

However, SA nodal cells are not the only pacemaker cells in the heart, and if they fail, other pacemaker cells found in the heart will take over and start generating action potentials.

The first pacemaker cells that will start generating action potentials if the SA node fails are the pacemaker cells in the atria, and if they fail, the pacemaker cells in the atrioventricular (AV) node take over. Finally, if all of these fail, the pacemaker cells in the Bundle of His and Purkinje fibers will take over and start the action potential generation. These pacemaker cells are called ectopic pacemakers and they allow the automaticity of the heart even if the SA node fails.
 
 

Option Analysis

✅ Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at a lower firing rate than the SA node:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at a higher firing rate than the SA node  :
Incorrect: The pacemaker cells in the SA node have the fastest firing rate. Other pacemaker cells have automaticity and are able to generate action potentials, but at a slower rate than that of the SA node.  
❌ Ectopic pacemaker cells generate the action potentials at the same firing rate than the SA node  :
Incorrect: The pacemaker cells in the SA node have the fastest firing rate. Other pacemaker cells have automaticity and are able to generate action potentials, but at a slower rate than that of the SA node.  
❌ Myocytes in the atria and ventricles generate their own action potentials separately:
Incorrect: Although the main pacemaker cells are the SA node, other pacemaker cells are able to generate action potentials if the SA node fails, which ensures that the heart keeps contracting at an appropriate rate and in synchronization between the right and left atria and ventricles.  
❌ Action potentials cannot be generated spontaneously:
Incorrect: The SA node is the main pacemaker of the heart but is not the only group of pacemaker cells. Other pacemaker cells in the heart are able to take over and generate action potentials should the SA node fail.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is involved in a motor vehicle accident and sustains massive blood loss. His initial blood pressure is steady at 100/70 mm Hg, but the trauma team is concerned about developing shock. Which of the following pathways is involved in the afferent limb of the physiologic response maintaining this patient's blood pressure?

choices.text: The aortic arch transmits via the vagus nerve to the midbrain
The aortic body transmits via the vagus nerve to the medulla
The carotid body transmits via the glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla
Carotid sinus transmits via the glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla
Carotid sinus transmits via the vagus nerve to the medulla

questions.solution:
The primary means by which the body deals with volume loss in the short term is via the arterial baroreflex. The body responds to short-term changes in blood pressure via the arterial baroreflex to maintain mean arterial pressure between 85 and 100 mm Hg. The decreased pressure causes the walls of the aortic arch and carotid sinus to become less stretched, and the baroreceptors start firing less frequently. The glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve carries that decreased signal to the cardiovascular centers of the brainstem (nucleus tractus solitarius in the medulla). These centers stimulate the sympathetic and inhibit the parasympathetic nervous systems from bringing the pressure back up to normal. Specifically, the vasomotor center increases the vasoconstrictive effect of the sympathetic nervous system, causing the arterioles to narrow, increasing the total peripheral arterial resistance and constriction of veins. This increases more blood return to the heart. Increased venous return means more preload, which also increases cardiac output.  Meanwhile, the cardiac accelerator center in the medulla is also stimulated, increasing the heart rate and contractility. In contrast, the cardiac decelerator center is deactivated, reducing the parasympathetic effects on the heart, which speeds up the heart rate. Combined, these effects result in an increased cardiac output (CO) and an increase in total peripheral resistance (TPR) which raises the blood pressure (BP) back to normal. In this case, these changes are essential in responding to severe hemorrhage.  


Option Analysis

❌ The aortic arch transmits via the vagus nerve to the midbrain:
Incorrect: There are minor contributors to the arterial baroreflex in the aortic arch that transmit via the vagus nerve, but they synapse at the nucleus tractus solitarius in the medulla, not the midbrain. Thus, this answer is incorrect.  
❌ The aortic body transmits via the vagus nerve to the medulla:
Incorrect: This answer is wrong because the aortic body is a chemoreceptor, not a baroreceptor. It will respond to a decreased PO2 (less than 60 mm Hg), increased PCO2, or decreased blood pH. These conditions may develop in this patient, but the dominant physiological stressor in this patient is hypovolemia.  
❌ The carotid body transmits via the glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla:
Incorrect: Carotid bodies are chemoreceptors, not baroreceptors, and respond to hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and academia. The baroreflex maintains blood pressure in the acute situation described in the stem.  
✅ Carotid sinus transmits via the glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Carotid sinus transmits via the vagus nerve to the medulla:
Incorrect: The baroreflex afferent limb consists of transmission from the carotid sinus  baroreceptors to the medulla via the glossopharyngeal nerve, not the vagus. The vagus is involved in the afferent limb from the aortic arch baroreceptors, not the carotid sinus baroreceptors. Thus, this answer is incorrect.

questions.text: A graduate student is conducting an experiment on a mouse. Using an echocardiogram, he is able to determine the percentage of the blood the left ventricle is pumping out with each contraction. This is the definition of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ejection fraction (EF) is a measurement, expressed as a percentage, of how much blood the left ventricle pumps out with each contraction. Mathematically, it is expressed as stroke volume over end-diastolic volume.

        EF = SV/EDV = EDV - ESV/EDV

A normal EF is usually between 50-70 percent. When examined using an echocardiogram, a significant number of patients with heart failure are found to have normal ventricular ejection fractions. This condition, which was previously called diastolic heart failure, is now referred to as heart failure with preserved ejection fractions. Patients with an EF of <40% are considered to have heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.  

Option Analysis

❌ Stroke volume  :
Incorrect: Stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped by the left ventricle of the heart in one contraction. Mathematically, it is the difference between the end-diastolic volume and the end-systolic volume. It can not be expressed as a percentage.  
✅ Ejection fraction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ​Cardiac output  :
Incorrect: Cardiac output is the amount of blood the heart pumps through the circulatory system in a minute. Mathematically, it is a product of stroke volume and heart rate.  
❌ Pulse pressure  :
Incorrect: Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressures. A change in pulse pressure is proportional to a change in stroke volume but inversely proportional to arterial compliance.  
❌ Mean arterial pressure  :
Incorrect: Mean arterial pressure (MAP) is the average arterial pressure throughout one cardiac cycle, systole, and diastole. Mathematically, it is a product of cardiac output and total peripheral resistance.

questions.text: A scientist is studying the effect of different pathologic processes on cardiac preload. An increase in preload will be observed in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Cardiac preload is defined as the ventricular wall stress at the end of diastole. Mathematically, it can be expressed by the Law of Laplace, which states that:

                        Wall stress = pressure (P) x radius (R) / 2 x wall thickness (W)

Since it is cumbersome to measure these values in vivo, a surrogate for cardiac preload used clinically is a left-ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV), which can be easily measured using an echocardiogram. LVEDV is affected by five factors, which are as follows:
 
  1.  Venous pressure and rate of venous return (VR): Decreased VR (e.g. hypovolemic states like dehydration or hemorrhage) decreases preload, whereas increased VR (e.g. hypervolemic conditions like early pregnancy) increases VR. 
  2.  Atrial contraction: Loss of atrial contraction (e.g. in atrial arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter) decreases LVEDV, resulting in reduced preload. 
  3.  Resistance from valves: Valvular abnormalities that cause decreased LVEDV (e.g. mitral stenosis) result in reduced preload, whereas those that increase LVEDV (e.g. aortic or pulmonary stenosis) increase preload. 
  4.  Ventricular compliance: Compliant, stretchy ventricles, such as that seen in dilated cardiomyopathy, increases preload, while non-compliant, stiff ventricles, such as that seen in ventricular hypertrophy, decrease preload. 
  5.  Heart rate: Normal heart rate allows adequate time for ventricles to fill, while tachycardia reduces the filling time, ultimately decreasing preload. 
Of note, cardiac preload is one of the main factors influencing how much blood the heart pumps out with each heartbeat (stroke volume). An increase in preload causes an increase in stroke volume.  

Option Analysis

❌ Mitral stenosis  :
Incorrect: Inflow resistance created by the narrowing of the atrioventricular valve, such as mitral stenosis and tricuspid stenosis, results in decreased filling of the ventricles and, therefore, reduced preload.  
❌ Dehydration:
Incorrect: Decrease in circulating blood volume (hypovolemia) in the context of dehydration leads to decreased end-diastolic volume and, therefore, reduced preload.  
❌ Loss of atrial contraction:
Incorrect: Loss of atrial contraction, common in atrial arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter), decreases the volume of blood that enters the ventricle, ultimately causing a decrease in end-diastolic volume and preload.  
✅ Dilated cardiomyopathy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sinus tachycardia:
Incorrect: Sinus tachycardia reduces the ventricular filling time, ultimately decreasing preload.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine visit. The patient currently has no complaints and came for medication refills. He has a past medical history of hypertension diagnosed 30 years ago. He has not been using his medications in the past several years but recently started taking them as prescribed after a family member died of a heart attack. The patient’s medications include amlodipine and losartan. Cardiac auscultation reveals an abnormal heart sound just before S1. Which of the following electrocardiographic findings are most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: P-wave in lead V1 and V2 over 1.5 mm
Bifid P-wave in lead II with a gap of over 40 ms separating the two peaks
Dominant R wave in V1 with R/S ratio > 1
Right axis deviation with an axis of 115 degrees
Deep S wave in lead V1 and tall R wave in lead V6

questions.solution:
This patient with chronic hypertension and medication noncompliance, together with auscultation revealing an S4 (abnormal heart sound just before S1), has most likely developed left ventricular hypertrophy. Electrocardiogram (ECG) of such patients reveals a deep S-wave in lead V1 and a tall R-wave in lead V6.

The most commonly used voltage criteria to identify left ventricular hypertrophy is that adding up the S-wave in V1 and the tallest R-wave in V5 or V6 has to be over 35 millimeters or 35 little boxes. Additional criteria include things like having an R-wave that goes on for longer than usual - typically over 50ms, ST-segment depression, and T-wave inversion in V5 or V6. These are signs that the left ventricle is straining during muscle contraction.

Left ventricular hypertrophy commonly develops due to chronic systemic hypertension, or elevated systemic blood pressure, since the left ventricle needs more muscle so that it can eject blood against higher pressures.
 

Option Analysis

❌ P-wave in lead V1 and V2 over 1.5 mm:
Incorrect: In right atrial enlargement, the extra right atrial muscle tissue results in a large P wave in leads V1 and V2, often over 1.5 mm. One of the common causes of right atrial enlargement includes tricuspid stenosis, as well as severe pulmonary hypertension.  
❌ Bifid P-wave in lead II with a gap of over 40 ms separating the two peaks:
Incorrect: Bifid P-wave in lead II with a gap of over 40 ms separating the two peaks is seen in patients with left atrial enlargement. One of the common causes of left atrial enlargement includes mitral stenosis.  
❌ Dominant R wave in V1 with R/S ratio > 1:
Incorrect: A dominant R wave in V1 is a classic sign of right ventricular hypertrophy and it’s defined as one that is over 7mm tall or 7 little boxes and is larger than the S wave, making the R/S ratio >1.  
❌ Right axis deviation with an axis of 115 degrees:
Incorrect: Right axis deviation resulting in an axis of 110 degrees or more is seen in patients with right ventricular hypertrophy.  
✅ Deep S wave in lead V1 and tall R wave in lead V6:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents for evaluation of chest pain and dyspnea that worsens with exertion. Medical history is notable for untreated Streptococcal pharyngitis as a child. An echocardiogram is performed and reveals aortic stenosis. The patient is found to have a left ventricular wall thickness of T and a radius of R. The intraventricular pressure during systole is P. The patient is lost to follow-up and, upon returning a year later, is found to have a wall thickness of 1.2T and radius of 0.6R. Intraventricular pressure remains unchanged. Which of the following best characterizes decreased left ventricular wall stress over the past year?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with aortic stenosis, which led to an increase in cardiac afterload. Over time, the heart muscle will hypertrophy to reduce ventricular wall stress during systole. The change in ventricular wall stress can be calculated using the law of Laplace.

The law of Laplace states that the wall tension of a hollow cylinder or sphere is proportional to its pressure and radius. A modified version of this equation can be used to calculate ventricular wall stress and is as follows:
 

The first step to finding the change in ventricular wall stress is calculating the initial wall stress after one year. Next, the difference between these two values should be calculated, representing the change in wall stress:

                                          Initial ventricular wall stress = (P*R) / (2*T)

                     One-year ventricular wall stress = (P*0.6R) / (2*1.2T) = (P*R) / (4*T)

           Change in ventricular wall stress = (P*R) / (4*T) – (P*R) / (2*T) = - (P*R) / (4*T)

These equations demonstrate that ventricular hypertrophy, which increases wall thickness and decreases the inner radius of the ventricle, helps reduce wall stress.   

Option Analysis

❌ (PR)/(2T):
Incorrect: Ventricular wall stress can be calculated using the law of Laplace. Based on this law of physics, the patient’s initial left ventricular wall stress is (PR)/(2T), whereas a year later is (PR)/(4T). The decrease in left ventricular wall stress is the difference between these two values: (PR)/(4T).  
❌ (PR)/(T):
Incorrect: Ventricular wall stress can be calculated using the law of Laplace. Based on this law of physics, the patient’s initial left ventricular wall stress is (PR)/(2T), whereas a year later, it is (PR)/(4T). The decrease in left ventricular wall stress is the difference between these two values: (PR)/(4T).  
❌ PRT:
Incorrect: According to the law of Laplace, ventricular wall stress is inversely proportional to the wall thickness. Therefore, the variable T should appear in the denominator of the expression.  
✅ (PR)/(4T)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ (PR)/6  :
Incorrect: Wall tension of a hollow structure is determined by its radius and the pressure of its contents. However, this question asks for the change in wall stress, which considers pressure, radius, and wall thickness. As a result, the variable T (ventricular wall thickness) should be present in the correct answer.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effect that different pathologies have on cardiac physiology. Which of the following conditions will most likely result in a decreased cardiac afterload?
questions.solution:
Cardiac afterload is the amount of resistance that the ventricles must overcome during systole. The three factors contributing to afterload are systemic vascular resistance, aortic pressure, and valvular diseases. Conditions that increase afterload will lead to a decrease in stroke volume.
 
  •  Systemic vascular resistance measures how readily vessels allow blood to flow through them. Systemic vascular resistance can be affected by changes in the vessel lumen or blood viscosity. 
  •  Aortic pressure is the blood pressure at the root of the aorta. An increase in aortic pressure means the heart must contract harder and generate more pressure within the left ventricle to pump blood out. Therefore, an increase in aortic pressure will lead to an increase in afterload. 
  •  There is valvular disease. In aortic stenosis, the aortic valve does not fully open, and the heart must generate more pressure to eject blood during systole. In mitral regurgitation, the mitral valves do not fully close, and blood flows back from the left ventricle into the left atrium. As a result, less blood must be ejected into the systemic circulation. 

Option Analysis

❌ Aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Afterload is affected by systemic vascular resistance, aortic pressure, and valvular disease. In aortic stenosis, the aortic valve does not fully open, and the heart must generate more pressure to eject blood during systole. As a result, the condition will lead to increased afterload.  
❌ Systemic vasoconstriction:
Incorrect: Afterload is affected by systemic vascular resistance, aortic pressure, and valvular disease. Systemic vasoconstriction will increase vascular resistance and, in turn, increase afterload.  
❌ Polycythemia vera:
Incorrect: Polycythemia vera is a myeloproliferative disorder characterized primarily by the overproduction of red blood cells. The condition leads to increased blood viscosity, which can, in turn, increase systemic vascular resistance and afterload.  
❌ Adrenal aldosteronoma:
Incorrect: Afterload is affected by systemic vascular resistance, aortic pressure, and valvular disease. An aldosteronoma will lead to unregulated aldosterone secretion, which will cause hypertension refractory to medical treatment and increased afterload.  
✅ Acute mitral regurgitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A study is done to record the action potentials of the different cells in the heart. During the study, a myocyte action potential is recorded and is shown below. During which of the following phases do calcium ions influx into the myocyte causing contraction?
questions.solution:
The action potential is electrical activity across the cell membrane. In the heart, two distinct types of action potentials occur in 2 different types of cells, the pacemaker cells, and the cardiac myocytes.

The myocytes are the contractile units of the heart and make up the myocardium. Their action potential is characterized by 5 different phases:

Phase 4: Also known as the resting phase. It is the initial phase where the ion channels are mainly closed and the membrane potential is resting at -90 mV. Because of the presence of gap junctions between the myocytes, some positive ions leak from neighboring cells that are depolarized (mainly calcium ions) bringing the membrane potential up to -70 mV, which is the threshold potential for depolarization.
 
 
Phase 0: This is known as the depolarization phase. When the membrane potential reaches the threshold (-70 mV), the voltage-gated sodium channels open and the rapid influx of sodium into the cells brings the membrane potential up to +20 mV.
 
 
Phase 1: the initial repolarization phase. After the membrane potential of myocytes reaches +20 mV, depolarization ends and the sodium channels close. This is followed by the opening of the voltage-gated potassium channels. The efflux of potassium towards the outside of the cell causes the membrane potential to drop until phase 2 starts. The initial repolarization is responsible for the notch seen in the myocytes action potential.
 

Phase 2: the plateau phase. Shortly after the opening of the voltage-gated potassium channels in phase 1, voltage-gated calcium channels open and allow calcium ions to influx into the cells. In this phase, the inward current by calcium ions balances the outward current of potassium channels, and the membrane potential stabilizes, thus called the plateau phase. This phase is important in the myocyte action potential because it is responsible for the length of the action potential and the calcium influx is what actually causes the myocytes to contract.
 

Phase 3: the repolarization phase. Here the voltage-gated calcium channels close while the voltage-gated potassium channels remain open, and the potassium continues to efflux outside the cell bringing the membrane potential back to the resting potential (-90 mV), thus, marking the end of the action potential.  


Finally, few notable differences can be made between the action potentials of myocytes and skeletal muscles. First of all, myocytes are electrically coupled with gap junctions, while skeletal muscle cells are not. Additionally, the plateau phase in myocytes action potentials is absent in skeletal muscle action potentials. And finally, the influx of calcium ions in the plateau phase is required to induce the release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and, therefore, required for muscle contraction.  

Option Analysis

❌ Phase 0  :
Incorrect: Phase 0 is the depolarization phase of the myocytes and is characterized by an influx of sodium into the cells. However, calcium channels are closed in phase 0.  
❌ Phase 1  :
Incorrect: Phase 1 is also known as the initial repolarization phase and is characterized by an influx of potassium ions, not calcium ions.  
✅ Phase 2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Phase 3:
Incorrect: Phase 3 is the repolarization phase and the calcium channels close while the potassium channels are open, resulting in an efflux of potassium towards the outside of the cell, causing the membrane to drop back to -90 mV.  
❌ Phase 4  :
Incorrect: Phase 0 is the resting phase of the myocyte where all channels are expected to be closed.

questions.text: The conduction of the action potential in the mammalian heart is examined. The total time of action potential to reach from the sinoatrial (SA) node to the ventricles is estimated to be around 220 ms. However, it was noted that the action potential travels in certain areas of the heart faster than other areas. Which of the following represents the velocity of conduction of action potentials in the heart from the fastest to the slowest?

choices.text: His-Purkinje system > atria > ventricles > AV node
Atria > ventricles > His-Purkinje system > AV node
Ventricles > atria > His-Purkinje system > AV node
AV node > ventricles > atria > His-Purkinje system
AV node > atria > ventricles > His-Purkinje system

questions.solution:
Myocardial action potentials start in the pacemaker cells (most of the time in the sinoatrial [SA] node) and then propagate to the atria and the ventricles. The propagation of action potentials within the heart is rapid (around 220 ms) which allows the action potential to spread to the entire heart very fast and allows for coordinated contraction of the muscle.

The conduction of the action potential from one cell to another is due to the presence of gap junctions, which allow certain ions to flow from one depolarizing cell to the adjacent cell and cause depolarization in it.

However, the conduction velocity in the heart actually varies in different locations. After spontaneous depolarization in the SA node, the action potential spreads throughout the atria through the atrial conduction fibers at a rate of 1 ms, allowing the atria to contract together.

After that, the wave reaches the atrioventricular (AV) node in order to reach the ventricles. The AV node has the lowest conduction velocity in the entire heart at a rate of 0.1-0.5 ms. This is beneficial to allow the atria to contract and fill the ventricles before ventricular depolarization and contraction starts.

After that, the conduction travels through the His-Purkinje system, which has the highest conduction velocity of the heart (around 2-4 ms). This fast conduction allows the depolarization wave to reach both ventricles at the same time, allowing for coordinated contraction of the ventricles. Finally, within the ventricles, the conduction velocity is around 1 ms.  


Option Analysis

✅ His-Purkinje system > atria > ventricles > AV node:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Atria > ventricles > His-Purkinje system > AV node  :
Incorrect: The fastest area of conduction in the heart is the His-Purkinje system.  
❌ Ventricles > atria > His-Purkinje system > AV node:
Incorrect: The fastest area of conduction in the heart is the His-Purkinje system.  
❌ AV node > ventricles > atria > His-Purkinje system:
Incorrect: The fastest area of conduction in the heart is the His-Purkinje system, while the AV node is the slowest.  
❌ AV node > atria > ventricles > His-Purkinje system:
Incorrect: The fastest area of conduction in the heart is the His-Purkinje system, while the AV node is the slowest.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to his primary care provider for a follow-up visit. The patient was diagnosed with systolic heart failure several years ago. He has been experiencing significant edema in the bilateral lower extremities. An increase in which of the following factors is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with systolic heart failure (now called heart failure with reduced ejection fraction). In this condition, blood cannot be pumped efficiently and back up into the capillaries. As a result, there is an increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure, which leads to peripheral edema.

The net movement of water across capillaries is described using the Starling equation. The formula is as follows:
 
 
The equation states there are two types of forces acting within, and outside, the capillaries, that determine fluid movement. The capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc) pushes fluid out of the capillaries, whereas the interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi) pushes fluids into the capillaries. There are also osmotic pressures and these forces pull fluids in their direction. The capillary oncotic pressure (πc) pulls fluid into the capillaries, whereas the interstitial oncotic pressure (πi) pulls fluid into the interstitium.

The filtration coefficient (Kf) is not a force but instead determines the water permeability of the capillary walls. Lastly, there is the reflection coefficient (σ), which describes the capillary’s permeability to proteins. A coefficient of 1 means the capillary is impermeable to protein, whereas 0 means it is completely permeable.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Capillary hydrostatic pressure  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Interstitial lymphatic drainage  :
Incorrect: A decrease in interstitial lymphatic drainage results in interstitial fluid accumulation (lymphedema). Certain parasitic infections (e.g. filariasis) can block this lymphatic drainage, resulting in edema. It is not a significant cause of peripheral edema in patients with heart failure.  
❌ Capillary oncotic pressure  :
Incorrect: The Starling equation helps determine the direction of fluid flow across capillaries. An increase in capillary oncotic pressure would pull fluid from the interstitium into the capillaries, thereby reducing peripheral edema.  
❌ Interstitial oncotic pressure:
Incorrect: An increase in interstitial oncotic pressure can increase fluid outflow from the capillaries. However, given the patient’s history of systolic heart failure, he likely has poor cardiac output and backing up of blood into the capillaries. These changes would lead to an increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure, not interstitial oncotic pressure.  
❌ Capillary permeability  :
Incorrect: Inflammatory conditions (e.g., infection, vasculitis) and burns can increase capillary permeability and enable more fluid to extravasate into the interstitial space. However, capillary permeability is not typically affected in heart failure.

questions.text: An autopsy is performed to determine the cause of sudden death in a 23-year-old athlete while playing baseball. The horizontal section of the heart at the level of the ventricles reveals asymmetric ventricular septal hypertrophy. If this patient had a pre-participation sports screening, cardiac auscultation would have likely revealed a murmur that increased with the following maneuvers?
questions.solution:
The autopsy finding of this patient shows asymmetric ventricular septal hypertrophy, a finding characteristic of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). In HCM, obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) is expected, which produces a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur that is best heard in the left lower sternal border (LLSB).

Instances that decrease LV blood volume worsen LVOT obstruction and increase the intensity of the HCM murmur. These include a decrease in preload (e.g., with abrupt standing, straining phase of Valsalva) or a decrease in afterload (e.g. vasodilators like hydralazine). The opposite is true, i.e. conditions that increase preload (e.g. passive leg raise, squatting) or increase afterload (e.g. vasoconstrictor like phenylephrine) would increase LV blood volume, thereby improving LVOT obstruction and decreasing the intensity of the murmur.  

Option Analysis

❌ Passive leg raising:
Incorrect: Passive leg raise increases preload, which increases left ventricular blood volume, thereby improving LVOT obstruction and decreasing the intensity of the murmur.  
✅ Straining phase of Valsalva:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Squatting:
Incorrect: Squatting increases preload and afterload, both of which increase left ventricular blood volume, thereby improving LVOT obstruction and decreasing the intensity of the murmur.  
❌ Sustained handgrip:
Incorrect: Sustained handgrip increases afterload, increasing left ventricular blood volume, thereby improving LVOT obstruction and decreasing the intensity of the murmur.  
❌ Infusion of phenylephrine:
Incorrect: Infusion of phenylephrine (an alpha-1 receptor agonist) increases afterload, increasing left ventricular blood volume, thereby improving LVOT obstruction and decreasing the intensity of the murmur.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic for an evaluation of intermittent palpitations. The patient has not had any episodes of syncope, chest pain, shortness of breath, or vomiting. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed that shows an electrical abnormality representing the slowing of the conduction through the AV node. Which of the following is most likely to be abnormal in this patient’s ECG tracing?
questions.solution:
In a typical electrocardiogram (ECG) waveform, there is a P-wave (atrial depolarization), a QRS complex (ventricular depolarization), and a T-wave (ventricular repolarization). In addition, there are certain intervals, including the PR interval, the QRS complex, and the QT interval that help us differentiate normal from abnormal conduction.

The PR interval spans from the beginning of the p-wave to the beginning of the QRS complex. It is normally 0.12-0.20 seconds, which is three-to-five little boxes since each little box is 0.04 seconds.  Any deviation in the normal depolarization pathway from the SA node to the ventricles can change the PR interval. For example, an ectopic atrial focus is farther away from the AV node, resulting in a longer PR interval.

Another example is first degree or second degree (mobitz type I) heart block, which is when the electrical signal travels more slowly through the AV node than it normally does, causing the PR interval to lengthen beyond 0.2 seconds (as in this patient).

The QT interval is primarily a measure of ventricular repolarization. Prolongation of this interval (termed a prolonged QT) can result in lethal arrhythmias, specifically, torsades de pointes, which can degenerate into ventricular fibrillation and sudden cardiac death. Prolonged QT intervals usually result from drug therapy, hypokalemia, and/or hypomagnesemia.  

Option Analysis

❌ QT interval:
Incorrect: The QT interval spans from the beginning of the QRS complex to the end of the T-wave. It represents the ventricular systole, which is the entire span from depolarization through repolarization. It is not affected by nodal conduction abnormalities.  
✅ PR interval:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ST segment  :
Incorrect: After the heart depolarizes, there is a brief absence of electrical activity, making an isoelectric line before repolarization, called the ST segment. On the ECG, it corresponds to the area from the end of the QRS complex to the beginning of the T wave. It is not affected by nodal conduction abnormalities.  
❌ QRS complex  :
Incorrect: The QRS complex occurs when the depolarization signal goes through the pacemaker cells of the Bundle of His and the bundle branches down into the Purkinje fibers. The apex of the heart depolarizes, followed by depolarization of the base. It is not directly affected by AV node conduction abnormalities.  
❌ T wave:
Incorrect: T-wave is a result of ventricular repolarization that appears on the ECG as a positive deflection. It is not directly affected by nodal conduction abnormalities.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe headaches, nausea, and 1 episode of vomiting. The patient has a known history of metastatic breast cancer, non-responsive to multiple chemotherapeutic regimens. On arrival, she is lethargic and oriented only to herself. Her pulse is 50/min, respirations are 8/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 150/96 mm Hg. The findings in this patient result from which of the following primary changes?
questions.solution:
Increased intracranial pressure (ICP) results in a lack of oxygen in brain tissue and a restriction of cerebral blood flow in the brain. This is most commonly caused by a head injury, bleeding in the brain (i.e., hematoma or hemorrhage), tumor, infection, stroke, excess cerebrospinal fluid, or brain swelling.

Increased ICP activates the Cushing reflex, a nervous system response resulting in Cushing’s triad. As the ICP increases, it eventually becomes more significant than the mean arterial pressure, which typically must be greater than the ICP for the brain tissue to be adequately oxygenated. This difference in pressure causes a decrease in the cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) or the amount of blood and oxygen the brain receives, leading to the brain not receiving enough oxygen (also known as brain ischemia). To compensate for the lack of oxygen, the sympathetic nervous system is activated, causing an increase in systemic blood pressure and an initial increase in heart rate. The increased blood pressure then signals the carotid and aortic baroreceptors to start the parasympathetic nervous system, causing the heart rate to decrease. As the pressure in the brain continues to rise, the brain stem may become dysfunctional, resulting in irregular respirations followed by periods where breathing ceases completely. This progression is indicative of a worsening prognosis.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hypovolemia:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Hypovolemia does not cause the Cushing reflex.  
✅ Elevated intracranial pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypoxia:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. The primary disturbance is elevated ICP, which results in cerebral hypoxia.  
❌ Myocardial ischemia  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. The primary disturbance is elevated ICP, that results in cerebral ischemia.  
❌ Baroreceptor stimulation:
Incorrect: Baroreceptor stimulation is a part of the Cushing reflex that results in bradycardia.

questions.text: A graduate student is conducting an experiment to determine the effects of arterial compliance and stroke volume on pulse pressure. Which of the following best describes the effects that changes in the independent variables will have on the dependent variable?
questions.solution:
This question is asking how changes in stroke volume and arterial compliance will affect pulse pressure.

Pulse pressure is defined as the difference between systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP). Pulse pressure is directly proportional to stroke volume and inversely proportional to arterial compliance. An increase in stroke volume means more blood is ejected from the heart, which would result in an increased SBP and pulse pressure. Similarly, a decrease in vascular compliance means the ejected blood is pushing against a stiff vascular wall, which would also increase SBP and pulse pressure.

These physiological parameters can be illustrated via some clinical scenarios. One example is aortic stiffening, which can be due to natural aging or secondary to arteriosclerosis. The condition will lead to decreased arterial compliance. As a result, SBP will increase whereas DBP, which is determined by total peripheral resistance (provided chiefly by the arterioles), will remain largely unchanged.

As an aside, it is worth mentioning that in patients with significant aortic changes following chronic hypertension, stiffening of the aorta reduces the elastic reservoir capacity, and more blood runs off from each stroke volume during systole, which results in a reduced blood volume within the aorta at the onset of diastole, resulting in lower DBP.

Another example is aortic stenosis. In this condition, narrowing of the aortic valve interferes with the ejection of blood from the left ventricle into the aorta and results in decreased stroke volume. In turn, SBP and ultimately pulse pressure will decrease.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Pulse pressure is directly proportional to stroke volume and inversely proportional to arterial compliance. As a result, increased vascular compliance and unchanged stroke volume will result in decreased, not increased, pulse pressure.   
❌ :
Incorrect: In this set of experimental parameters, vascular compliance is increased and stroke volume decreased. These changes would mean that less blood is pushing against the arterial walls during systole and the walls can easily expand in response to blood leaving the heart. As a result, systolic blood pressure will decrease, diastolic blood pressure will remain largely unchanged (since it is determined by the total peripheral resistance, which is provided chiefly by the arterioles), and pulse pressure will ultimately decrease.   
❌ :
Incorrect: In this set of experimental parameters, stroke volume is increased. This change means that more blood is pushing against the arterial walls during systole. As a result, systolic blood pressure will increase, diastolic blood pressure will remain largely unchanged, and pulse pressure will ultimately increase.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Pulse pressure is directly proportional to stroke volume and inversely proportional to arterial compliance. As a result, decreased vascular compliance and increased stroke volume will result in increased pulse pressure.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate is evaluated in the newborn nursery. He was born via normal vaginal delivery to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, with an intrauterine pregnancy at 34 weeks gestation. He demonstrates a strong cry and moves all his extremities. Physical examination shows that the patient’s torso and upper extremities are pink, while his lower extremities have a bluish hue. Vitals are within normal limits for age. Which of the following will most likely be heard on the auscultation of the patient’s chest?

choices.text: Continuous systolic and diastolic murmur in left infraclavicular area
Holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border
Holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex radiating to the axilla
Holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex with a mid-diastolic rumble at the left sternal border

questions.solution:
This neonate with lower extremity “differential” cyanosis, who is born preterm (at 34 weeks gestation), most likely has patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which is characterized by a continuous “machine-like” murmur that is best heard in the left infraclavicular area, with maximal intensity at S2.

Typically, the ductus arteriosus carries deoxygenated blood from the pulmonary artery into the descending aorta during fetal development. When the infant starts breathing at birth, the rise in oxygen concentration and decline in prostaglandin secretion (from the placenta) leads to the closure of ductus arteriosus. If it remains open after birth, declining pulmonary resistance makes it a left-to-right shunt.

Risk factors for PDA include preterm birth, congenital rubella, and hypoxia (e.g. cyanotic heart diseases). Short PDA can be asymptomatic, while others cause lower extremity (differential) cyanosis.  Uncorrected PDA can lead to Eisenmenger syndrome.  

Option Analysis

❌ Rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur  :
Incorrect: Mitral stenosis causes a rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. It is rare in newborns and is not usually associated with differential cyanosis.  
✅ Continuous systolic and diastolic murmur in left infraclavicular area:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border  :
Incorrect: Ventricular septal defect causes a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. It may lead to central cyanosis but is not associated with differential cyanosis in newborns.  
❌ Holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex radiating to the axilla:
Incorrect: Mitral regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur that radiates to the axilla at the cardiac apex. It is rare in newborns and is not usually associated with differential cyanosis.  
❌ Holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex with a mid-diastolic rumble at the left sternal border  :
Incorrect: A complete atrioventricular canal defect can present with auscultatory findings of aortic regurgitation (holosystolic murmur, best heard at apex) and increased pulmonary venous return (mid-diastolic rumble). It is seen in patients with Down syndrome and presents with central cyanosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is found to have supraventricular tachycardia on an EKG. The physician starts to perform a carotid massage. Which changes will be seen in response to the carotid massage?
questions.solution:
Carotid sinus is the dilated region superior to bifurcation of carotid arteries. Distinct afferent nerve fibers in the carotid sinus join the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) to stimulate medullary centers directly. The baroreceptors are activated when the pressure in the carotid sinus rises. The afferent fibers in the glossopharyngeal nerve release glutamate to excite neurons in the nucleus of the tractus solitarius (NTS). Excitatory (glutamate) projections extend from the NTS to the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM), where they stimulate γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA)-secreting inhibitory neurons that project to the rostral ventrolateral medulla RVLM. Excitatory projections also extend from the NTS to the cardiac vagal motor neurons in the nucleus ambiguus. Thus, increased baroreceptor discharge inhibits sympathetic nerve activity and excites vagal nerve activity to increase AV node refractory period, causing vasodilation, hypotension, and decreased cardiac output.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased cardiac output  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Carotid massage stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system, eventually decreasing cardiac output.  
✅ Decreased heart rate  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased blood pressure:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Carotid massage stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system, eventually decreasing blood pressure.  
❌ Vasoconstriction:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Carotid massage stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system, which would eventually cause vasodilation.  
❌ Increased preload:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Carotid massage stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system, which would eventually cause venodilation, peripheral blood pooling, and decreased cardiac preload.

questions.text: A group of researchers involved in studying chemoreceptors find that patients with COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) have elevated levels of carbon dioxide in their blood without the expected physiologic compensatory changes. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Patients with chronic carbon dioxide elevation (e.g., COPD, obesity hypoventilation syndrome) develop central chemoreceptor tolerance. Central chemoreceptors include specialized neurons in the medulla that, when stimulated, result in an increase in blood pressure via increased sympathetic outflow. The primary factors that stimulate this response include an increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide, and a decrease in blood pH, with negligible effects of decreased partial pressure of oxygen.

Patients with COPD are unable to expel carbon dioxide, and over time this results in hypercapnia. The body tries to compensate for subsequent chronic respiratory acidosis in COPD patients by retaining more bicarbonate to overcome the associated acidosis. Over time, central chemoreceptors become more tolerant of elevated pCO2 levels, and respiratory drive shifts to a hypoxic drive driven by low oxygen levels rather than elevated pCO2 levels.

Option Analysis

✅ Central chemoreceptor tolerance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Peripheral chemoreceptor tolerance:
Incorrect: Chronic hypercapnia in patients with COPD is largely mediated by central, rather than peripheral chemoreceptor tolerance.  
❌ Increased bicarbonate secretion:
Incorrect: To compensate for elevated pCO2 levels, patients with COPD will retain bicarbonate to maintain a neutral pH. Therefore, bicarbonate ion secretion will decrease, not increase.  
❌ Baroreceptor tolerance:
Incorrect: Baroreceptors in the aortic arch and carotid sinus are sensitive to blood pressure changes. Baroreceptors are not involved in maintaining homeostasis in patients with chronically elevated carbon dioxide levels.  
❌ Decreased secretion of antidiuretic hormone  :
Incorrect: The antidiuretic hormone is not involved in mediating the effects of chronic hypercapnia in patients with COPD.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine visit. She denies any active complaints. Their past medical history is significant for recurrent pharyngitis when she was young. She has no medical problems and takes no medications. Cardiac auscultation reveals a high-pitched, blowing murmur best heard in the 5th intercostal space at the left midclavicular line throughout systole. Which of the following properties is characteristic of this patient's abnormal auscultation finding?

choices.text: Decrease in intensity with passive leg raise
Radiates to the right sternal border

questions.solution:
Heart murmurs can be characterized by the location where they are best heard, their timing within the cardiac cycle, and associated findings. Systolic murmurs occur between the first and second heart sounds. This patient, who has a holosystolic, high-pitched, blowing murmur that is best heard in the mitral area (5th intercostal space at the left midclavicular line), most likely has mitral regurgitation. Given her prior history of recurrent childhood pharyngitic infections, the mitral regurgitation is likely caused by rheumatic fever. In patients with rheumatic fever with cardiac complications, mitral regurgitation typically occurs before the development of mitral stenosis. The murmur of mitral regurgitation radiates to the axilla on auscultation.

Other commonly encountered causes of systolic murmurs include:
 
  •  Ventricular septal defect, which causes a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (LLSB) 
  •  Aortic stenosis causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur that is best heard in the right second intercostal space. It radiates to the carotids in the neck. 
  •  Pulmonic stenosis causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur best heard in the left second intercostal space. It can also cause widening of the S2 split. 
  •  Tricuspid regurgitation causes a holosystolic, blowing murmur that is best heard at the LLSB and radiates to the right lower sternal border. 
  •  Mitral valve prolapse causes a late systolic crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click that is best heard over the apex. 

Option Analysis

❌ Decrease in intensity with passive leg raise:
Incorrect: Passive leg raise increases venous return in the vena cava, leading to increased preload. It increases, not decreases, the intensity of mitral regurgitation murmur.  
❌ Presents with an opening snap  :
Incorrect: Rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur of mitral stenosis usually presents with an opening snap caused by an abrupt halt in leaflet motion after rapid opening due to fusion at the tips of the leaflets. It is not seen in mitral regurgitation.  
❌ Radiates to the neck  :
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur that is best heard in the second intercostal space on the right and radiates to the carotids in the neck.  
✅ Radiates to the axilla:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Radiates to the right sternal border:
Incorrect: Tricuspid regurgitation causes a holosystolic, blowing murmur that is best heard at the left lower sternal border and radiates to the right lower sternal border.

questions.text: An experiment is done on a cardiac myocyte action potential propagation to determine the effects of each part. In one aspect of the experiment, a new conduction pathway between the atria and ventricles is implanted and has a higher conduction rate compared to the native conduction system, the atrioventricular node. Which of the following is expected to happen as a result of this new pathway?

choices.text: Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume (LVEDV)

questions.solution:
Action potentials in the heart start in the pacemaker cells, and the most common location is the sinoatrial (SA) node given their automaticity and ability to fire action potentials on their own at a higher rate than any other part of the heart. After the pacemaker cells in the SA node initiate an action potential, it travels through the conduction system to the myocytes of the atria and the ventricles causing them to contract.

First, the wave spreads to the atria through the fast conducting system called the atrial internodal tract, which ensures that the action potential spreads to the right and left atria, and to all cells within each atria at almost the same time, and therefore, the atria contracts at the same time ejecting blood into the ventricles.

At the same time, the action potential is also sent to the atrioventricular node (AV node) to reach the heart. In the AV node there is a notable slowing in the propagation of the action potential into the ventricles. This delay is due to two reasons: 1. The AV nodal cells are small in diameter, and therefore more resistant to electrical current 2. The AV node depolarization is mediated by the influx of calcium ions, not sodium ions. Calcium influx is slower than sodium influx and, therefore, delays the action potential.

Because the AV node is the place where the action potential travels from the SA node and the atria into the ventricles, this conduction delay is very important. It is this delay that allows the ventricles to fill completely before they depolarize and contract, thus maintaining the stroke volume and cardiac output.
 
 

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased left ventricular stroke volume  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased left ventricular stroke volume:
Incorrect: If the delay in the AV node is eliminated, it will give less time for the ventricles to fill, thus causing decreased ventricular stroke volume.  
❌ Increased cardiac output  :
Incorrect: If the delay between atrial contraction and ventricular contraction is shortened, it will give less time for the ventricles to fill, thus causing decreased cardiac output.  
❌ Decreased left atrial end-diastolic pressure  :
Incorrect: Because the atria will have less time to completely eject blood in the ventricles, some blood will remain in the atria, and therefore, the atrial end-diastolic pressure is expected to increase.  
❌ Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume (LVEDV)  :
Incorrect: If the delay in the AV node is eliminated, it will give less time for the ventricles to fill, thus causing decreased LVEDV.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man comes to the clinic to re-establish care. The patient was lost to follow-up 40 years ago when he traveled out of the states. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus. The patient takes amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, and metformin inconsistently. Temperature is 36.6 °C (98 °F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/95 mmHg. Electrocardiogram ECG) is performed and is shown below. An ECG from his previous medical records, 40 years ago, is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of changes seen in this patient’s ECG tracing?
 

Reproduced from: EKG.md
questions.solution:
The axis of an electrocardiogram (ECG) is the mean QRS vector, which is the size and direction of the depolarization wave as it moves through the ventricles. Normally, the QRS axis aims downward and to the left in relation to the body, also called the normal axis. It appears on the ECG as a positive deflection in leads I and aVF (meaning a positive charge is traveling towards a positive electrode) and a negative deflection in aVR (a positive charge traveling towards a negative electrode).  



If the vector is positive in lead I and negative (between -30 to -90) in aVF, then it could be considered left axis deviation (LAD). Common causes of LAD include left ventricular hypertrophy, left bundle branch block, or when the right ventricle becomes damaged and loses healthy tissue.

If the opposite happens, and the vector is negative in lead I and positive in aVF, then it’s in the quadrant between +90 and +180 degrees, at which it is called right axis deviation (RAD). Common causes include right ventricular hypertrophy, right bundle branch block, or left lateral wall infarction. Finally, if the vector is negative in both lead I and aVF, then it’s a very rare case called extreme right axis deviation between -90 and +180 degrees. This can sometimes happen when there’s an ectopic focus that causes depolarization to start from the bottom of the ventricles, and travel in the reverse direction (ventricular pacing), or due to misplacement of leads.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Right bundle branch block:
Incorrect: Right bundle branch block (RBBB) causes delayed activation of the right ventricle, resulting in an rsR' pattern in lead V1 and a wide negative S wave in the left-right lead V6, none of which are seen in this patient’s ECG tracing. Moreover, RBBB is associated with right-axis deviation.  
❌ First degree AV block  :
Incorrect: First-degree AV block appears on the ECG as a prolonged PR interval. This patient’s ECG tracing shows a normal PR interval, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Lateral wall myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Lateral wall myocardial infarction is associated with right axis deviation, which appears as QRS-complexes being negative in lead I and positive in aVF. This patient’s ECG tracing is opposite to these findings, making left-axis deviation more likely.  
✅ Left ventricular hypertrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Right ventricular hypertrophy:
Incorrect: Right ventricular hypertrophy is associated with right axis deviation, which appears as QRS-complexes being negative in lead I and positive in aVF. This patient’s ECG tracing is opposite to these findings, making left-axis deviation more likely.

questions.text: A patient is participating in a clinical trial and takes a drug that improves cardiac contractility. At baseline, the patient’s end-diastolic volume is 120 ml, ejection fraction is 60%, and heart rate is 60/min. After taking the medication, the patient’s end-diastolic volume is 100 ml, ejection fraction is 70%, and heart rate is 70/min. Which of the following best characterizes the increase in cardiac output after taking the new medication?
questions.solution:
This question is asking for the change in cardiac output (CO) after the patient took the medication. To answer this question, it is essential to understand the relation between stroke volume, ejection fraction, and cardiac output.  

Stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped out of the left ventricle during each systolic contraction. The stroke volume can be calculated by finding the difference between the left ventricular end-diastolic volume and end-systolic volume. Alternatively, it can be calculated by multiplying the left ventricular end-diastolic volume by the ejection fraction, which is the percentage of blood pumped out of a chamber during each contraction.  

Stroke volume = EDV – ESV = EDV*EF   

EDV: End diastolic volume  
 ESV: End systolic volume  
    EF: Ejection fraction

Cardiac output, on the other hand, is the total volume of blood the left ventricle ejects in a given period of time. It can be calculated by multiplying stroke volume and heart rate.

 Cardiac output = SV*HR   
   SV: Stroke volume  
    HR: Heart rate

Using these equations, we are able to answer the original question as follows:  

Baseline:  
Stroke volume = EDV*EF = 120 ml * 60% = 72 ml  
Cardiac output = SV*HR = 72 ml * 60/min = 4,320 ml/min  

After taking inotropic medication:  
Stroke volume = EVF*EF = 100 ml * 70% = 70 ml  
Cardiac output = SV*HR = 70 ml * 70/min = 4,900 ml/min  

Change in cardiac output = 4,900 - 4,320 = 580 ml ≈ 600 ml  

Option Analysis

❌ 250 ml/min  :
Incorrect: Cardiac output is equal to the product of heart rate and stroke volume. The heart rate is provided whereas the stroke volume must be calculated by multiplying the end-diastolic volume by the ejection fraction. Using these equations, the baseline stroke volume is 72/ml (120 ml * 60%) and cardiac output is 4,320 ml/min (72 ml * 60/min). After taking the drug, the stroke volume is 70 ml (100 ml * 70%) and cardiac output is 4,900 ml/min (70 ml * 70/min). Thus, the change in cardiac output is 580 ml/min.    
❌ 420 ml/min  :
Incorrect: Cardiac output is equal to the product of heart rate and stroke volume. The heart rate is provided whereas the stroke volume must be calculated by multiplying the end-diastolic volume by the ejection fraction. Using these equations, the baseline stroke volume is 72/ml (120 ml * 60%) and cardiac output is 4,320 ml/min (72 ml * 60/min). After taking the drug, the stroke volume is 70 ml (100 ml * 70%) and cardiac output is 4,900 ml/min (70 ml * 70/min). Thus, the change in cardiac output is 580 ml/min.  
✅ 600 ml/min  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 4,300 ml/min  :
Incorrect: The baseline cardiac output for this patient is around 4,300 ml/min. In contrast, this question is asking about the change in cardiac output after taking the new medication.  
❌ 4,900 ml/min  :
Incorrect: The baseline cardiac output for this patient is around 4,900 ml/min. In contrast, this question is asking about the change in cardiac output after taking the new medication.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with intermittent substernal chest pain for the past 2 hours. The pain started when the patient was shoveling the snow in his driveway and did not improve with rest. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed which shows ST-segment depression in leads I, II, and V4-6. Which of the following options will help in differentiating ischemia from infarction?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia and electrocardiogram (ECG) findings of ST depression in leads I, II, and V4-6 is most likely having chest pain of cardiac origin. Serum cardiac enzymes (e.g. troponin) should be obtained to rule out non-ST segment myocardial infarction (NSTEMI).

Cardiac chest pain at rest with ST depressions on the ECG can be secondary to unstable angina or NSTEMI. Unstable angina occurs secondary to incomplete occlusion, causing transient hypoxic injury due to decreased blood flow to the subendocardial tissue and results in no leaking of cardiac enzymes (e.g., troponin, CK-MB) in the blood. NSTEMI, on the other hand, occurs when there is subendocardial infarction and necrosis of the involved tissue secondary to prolonged ischemia. The enzymes leak from the dead subendocardial cells, resulting in an elevation in cardiac biomarkers.

Of note, if the tissue infarction is transmural (involving the entire thickness of the myocardium), it results in ST elevation in the corresponding leads together with T wave inversions and pathologic Q waves, called ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).
 

Option Analysis

❌ T wave inversions:
Incorrect: T-wave inversions are nonspecific and can be seen in angina, NSTEMI, or STEMI. Of note, some T-wave inversion can be normal in leads III, aVR, and V1, but any sign of T wave inversion in leads V2-V6 is abnormal.  
✅ Serum troponins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Response to nitroglycerine:
Incorrect: Chest pain secondary to cardiac injury may or may not respond to nitroglycerine depending on the extent of the injury and is nonspecific in differentiating ischemia from infarction.  
❌ Serum brain natriuretic peptide:
Incorrect: Serum brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) is usually used in the evaluation of heart failure. It cannot differentiate between the types of cardiac injury.  
❌ Exercise stress test:
Incorrect: Exercise stress tests are contraindicated in patients with unstable angina and ongoing myocardial infarction. It is used for the evaluation of stable angina.

questions.text: A group of scientists are studying the function and pathway of central and peripheral chemoreceptors. Which of the following is most likely to stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors in mediating breathing and blood pressure dynamics?

choices.text: Decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen
Increase in the partial pressure of oxygen
Increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide

questions.solution:
Chemoreceptors refer to specialized neurons involved in eliciting reflex ventilatory, cardiovascular, and humoral responses to maintain homeostasis. There are two types of chemoreceptors in the human body, central, and peripheral, with peripheral chemoreceptors being the most sensitive to decreases in the partial pressure of oxygen.

Peripheral chemoreceptors include specialized neurons in the carotid bodies and aortic arch that, when stimulated, increase sympathetic outflow resulting in an increase in total peripheral pressure and cardiac output. The primary factors that stimulate this response include a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen, an increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide, and a decrease in blood pH.

Central chemoreceptors include specialized neurons in the medulla that, when stimulated, result in an increase in blood pressure via increased sympathetic outflow. The primary factors that stimulate this response include an increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide, and a decrease in blood pH, with negligible effects of decreased partial pressure of oxygen.  

Option Analysis

✅ Decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increase in the partial pressure of oxygen:
Incorrect: A decrease, not an increase in the partial pressure of oxygen, mediates the chemoreceptor reflex in the aortic arch and carotid bodies.  
❌ Increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide:
Incorrect: While an increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood may also stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors, they are more sensitive to decreases in oxygen. Central chemoreceptors in the medulla are more sensitive to an increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide.  
❌ Increase in blood pH:
Incorrect: Neither central nor peripheral chemoreceptors are particularly sensitive to an increase in blood pH. In contrast, peripheral chemoreceptors and central chemoreceptors are particularly sensitive to an increase in pCO2 and a decrease in blood pH.  
❌ Decreased blood pressure:
Incorrect: Baroreceptors in the aortic arch and carotid sinus are sensitive to blood pressure changes. Chemoreceptors in these locations are most sensitive to decreased blood oxygen.

questions.text: A patient participating in a clinical trial takes a new drug that increases cardiac contractility. The patient’s left ventricular ejection fraction increases from 55% to 65% after taking the medication. Via which of the following mechanisms does this new drug most likely work?
questions.solution:
This question is asking which of the listed changes will lead to an increase in cardiac contractility. Among the answer choices, only an elevation in intracellular calcium levels will increase cardiac contractility.

Cardiac contractility is a measure of the strength with which cardiomyocytes contract. Factors that increase intracellular calcium will stimulate cardiac contractility. Examples of such factors include:

1) Sympathetic stimulation activates β1-receptors. This change promotes downstream phosphorylation of proteins like sarcolemmal calcium channels on the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) membrane, increasing SR’s ability to release calcium. Furthermore, sympathetic stimulation promotes phospholamban phosphorylation, a protein found on the SR membrane that regulates calcium ATPase. This change increases calcium ATPase activity, bringing more calcium into the SR. Thus, more calcium can be released during subsequent depolarizations. Finally, phosphorylation of plasma membrane L-type calcium channels will increase their permeability, allowing more extracellular calcium entry into the cardiomyocyte.

2) Increased heart rate means more action potentials per unit of time. Each action potential’s inward calcium influx increases the total calcium that enters the cell. With more significant amounts of calcium within the cell, the sarcoplasmic reticulum also accumulates more calcium for subsequent action potentials.

3) Inhibition of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump will indirectly decrease the activity of the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger and result in increased intracellular calcium levels. Of note, the inotropic drug digoxin works via this mechanism of action.

In contrast, factors that decrease cardiac contractility include:

1) Parasympathetic stimulation activates M2 receptors. This change inhibits calcium channels and prevents calcium from entering the cardiomyocytes.

2) Decreased heart rate 

3) Activation of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump 
 
  

Option Analysis

❌ Activation of Na+/K+ ATPase pumps:
Incorrect: Activation of the Na+/K+ ATPase pumps will indirectly increase the activity of the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger, which pumps calcium out of cells. As a result, intracellular calcium levels will decrease and cardiac contractility.  
❌ Antagonization of postsynaptic β1-receptors  :
Incorrect: β1-receptors are part of the sympathetic nervous system and increase cardiac contractility. Drugs antagonizing β1-receptors, such as beta-blockers, will lead to decreased cardiac contractility.  
❌ Dephosphorylation of phospholamban:
Incorrect: Phospholamban is a protein found on the sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane. It regulates calcium ATPase, a pump that transports calcium from the cytoplasm into the sarcoplasmic reticulum. When phospholamban is dephosphorylated, calcium ATPase activity decreases, and less calcium is uptaken into the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
