As a result, less calcium can be released during subsequent depolarizations, decreasing cardiac contractility.  
✅ Elevation of intracellular calcium levels  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stimulation of M2 receptors:
Incorrect: Muscarinic receptors are part of the parasympathetic nervous system. Drugs that stimulate muscarinic receptors, particularly the M2 receptor, will result in decreased cardiac contractility.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents for evaluation of right calf swelling. An ultrasound is performed and the patient is found to have a blood clot occluding half the luminal diameter of the right popliteal vein. At baseline, the patient’s right popliteal vein has a resistance of R. The pressure gradient across the vessel is P and the rate of blood flow is Q. Assuming the pressure gradient is unchanged, which of the following best characterizes the new vascular resistance and flow rate?
questions.solution:
This question is asking how changes in blood vessel diameter will affect vascular resistance and blood flow. To answer this question, it is essential to understand the factors affecting vascular resistance as well as the relationship between vascular resistance, pressure, and flow.

Vascular resistance describes the impediment to blood flow through a vessel and can be calculated via the following equation:
 
 
According to the equation, resistance is proportional to the vessel’s length, and blood viscosity (how thick a fluid is). In other words, an increase in blood viscosity (e.g. polycythemia) or vessel length will lead to an increase in resistance. In contrast, resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel’s radius. Thus, if the vessel radius were halved, as in this vignette, then resistance would increase 16-fold.

The relation between flow rate, pressure gradient, and vascular resistance is demonstrated via the following equation:
 

Therefore, an increase in resistance will lead to a decrease in blood flow, assuming the pressure gradient remains unchanged. In this vignette, since the vascular resistance increased from R to 16R, the flow will decline from Q to Q/16.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius. Occlusion of half the vessel lumen will cause the radius to half and resistance to increase 16-fold (16R). The increase in resistance will in turn cause the flow rate to decrease.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius. Occlusion of half the vessel lumen will cause the radius to half and resistance to increase 16-fold (16R). The increase in resistance will in turn cause the flow rate to decrease.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius. As a result, a decrease in vessel radius by one-half will lead to a 16-fold increase in resistance (16R). Furthermore, blood flow is inversely proportional to resistance. This means the 16-fold increase in resistance will cause the flow rate to be 1/16th of the original (Q/16).   
❌ :
Incorrect: Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius. As a result, a decrease in vessel radius by one-half will lead to a 16-fold increase in resistance (16R). Furthermore, blood flow is inversely proportional to resistance, which means an increase in resistance will result in decreased blood flow.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic to establish care. The patient does not have any complaints. She does not have chest pain, dizziness, palpitations, or shortness of breath. Cardiac auscultation in the left 5th intercostal space reveals an early diastolic high-frequency sound followed by a mid-to-late diastolic murmur. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Heart murmurs can be characterized by the location where they are best heard, their timing within the cardiac cycle, and associated findings. Diastolic murmurs are heard after the second heart sound (S2). The auscultatory findings of a mid-to-late diastolic murmur with associated opening snap (early diastolic high-frequency sound) make the diagnosis of mitral stenosis (MS) most likely. An abrupt halt causes the opening snap in leaflet motion after rapid opening due to fusion at the tips of the leaflets.

Other commonly encountered causes of diastolic murmurs include:
 
  •  Tricuspid stenosis, which causes the same murmur like that of mitral stenosis best heard at the left lower sternal border. The inspiratory accentuation aids in differentiation from the murmur of mitral stenosis. 
  •  Aortic regurgitation causes a high-pitched, blowing, early diastolic decrescendo murmur. It can be best heard at the base (in aortic root dilation) or left sternal border (in valvular disease). 
  •  Pulmonic regurgitation also causes the same murmur as aortic regurgitation and radiates to the left sternal border, making differentiation difficult. When it occurs as an isolated defect, its murmur may increase with inspiration. It is usually seen in patients with pulmonary hypertension. 

Option Analysis

❌ Aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur that is best heard in the right second intercostal space. It radiates to the carotids in the neck.  
✅ Mitral stenosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aortic regurgitation:
Incorrect: Aortic regurgitation causes a high-pitched, blowing, early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the base (in aortic root dilation) or left sternal border (in valvular disease).  
❌ Ventricular septal defect  :
Incorrect: Ventricular septal defect causes a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (LLSB).  
❌ Mitral valve prolapse  :
Incorrect: Mitral valve prolapse causes a late systolic crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click best heard over the apex.

questions.text: During an evaluation of the action potential of the heart, some cells were identified to be responsible for the rate of the heart. These cells are located in the right atrium near the opening of the superior vena cava. The action potential of these cells is recorded and shown below. It was found that the slope of phase 4 (marked with the blue dot) determines the rate at which the heart contracts. Which of the following events occur during this phase?

choices.text: Influx of sodium ions into the cell
Influx of calcium ions into the cell
Efflux of potassium ions outside the cell
Efflux of chloride ions outside the cell
Influx of potassium ions into the cell

questions.solution:
Pacemaker cells are where the action potential of the heart starts; therefore, they are responsible for setting the rhythm and the rate of the heart. These cells continuously generate action potentials that are then conducted to the rest of the heart. The most important pacemaker cells are the sinoatrial (SA) nodes located in the right atrium near the opening of the superior vena cava. Additionally, the atrioventricular (AV) node is a small structure in the heart, near the coronary sinus on the interatrial septum, which also contains pacemaker cells. Other pacemaker cells are also found in the internodal tract, the Bundle of His, and the Purkinje fibers.

The action potential in the pacemaker cells is different from the rest of the heart, and is divided into 3 main phases: phase 4, phase 0, and phase 3.

Phase 4, also known as the pacemaker phase, is unique to the pacemaker cells. In this phase, there is a gradual depolarization due to the slow influx of sodium ions into the cells through the  hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated channel (HCN channel); these may sometimes be referred to as the “funny” current (If). This slow influx of sodium brings the membrane potential from -65 mV to the threshold of the pacemaker cells -40 mV. The slope of this phase determines the heart rate.
 

Phase 0, is the depolarization phase. Once the action potential of the pacemaker reaches the threshold of -40 mV, voltage-gated calcium channels open and the influx of calcium ions into the cells causes depolarization and brings the membrane potential up to +10 mV. Note that the depolarization of the pacemaker cells is due to the influx of calcium ions, and not sodium ions unlike the myocardial cells.
 
 
Phase 3, is the repolarization phase. Finally, once depolarization is complete, the voltage-gated calcium channels close and the potassium channels open. This results in a rapid efflux of potassium ions outside the cells bringing the membrane potential back to -65 mV or even lower. During this phase, both the HCN channels bringing sodium ions in and the potassium channels bringing potassium ions out of the cell are open; however, because much more potassium ions leave than sodium enters the cell, the membrane potential drops. After phase 3 is done, the action potential is complete, and the cell enters phase 4 again to start a new action potential.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Influx of sodium ions into the cell  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Influx of calcium ions into the cell  :
Incorrect: Depolarization of the pacemaker cells (phase 0) is due to the influx of calcium ions into the cells. However, in phase 4, only sodium ions are open, and calcium channels are closed.  
❌ Efflux of potassium ions outside the cell:
Incorrect: Efflux of potassium ions outside the cell is responsible for phase 3 (repolarization phase) of the action potential in pacemaker cells. Phase 4 is due to an influx of sodium ions.  
❌ Efflux of chloride ions outside the cell  :
Incorrect: Phase 4 of the action potential in the pacemaker is due to the influx of sodium ions into the cell, not the efflux of chloride ions outside the cell.  
❌ Influx of potassium ions into the cell  :
Incorrect: Phase 4 of the action potential in the pacemaker is due to the influx of sodium ions into the cell, not the influx of potassium ions into the cells.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe midsternal chest pain. The patient reports 2 episodes of non-bloody emesis and diaphoresis since the start of the chest pain half an hour ago. Blood pressure is 110/75 and pulse is 89/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed based on which a provisional diagnosis of inferior wall myocardial infarction is made. Which of the following patterns of ECG changes are most likely seen in this patient?

choices.text: ST-elevation in leads I, V5, and aVL
ST-elevation in leads V1 and V2
ST-elevation in leads V3 and V4
ST-elevation in leads II, III, and aVF
ST-depression in leads I and V5

questions.solution:
The electrocardiogram (ECG) records the flow of electrical impulses throughout the heart. Depolarization current flowing towards a positive electrode causes an upward deflection in the reading. A total of 12 leads are used in a standard ECG reading which is as follows:
 
  •  Six precordial electrodes (V1-V6): These electrodes are lined in the horizontal plane of the heart, collectively known as the chest leads. 
  •  Three augmented vector leads (aVR, aVL, and aVF): These electrodes are lined in the coronal plane. 
  •  Three bipolar limb leads (lead I, II, and III): Lined in the coronal plane, these leads use two electrodes instead of one. Lead 1 uses the right arm as the negative pole and the left arm as the positive, forming a vector that goes to the right. Lead 2 uses aVR as negative and aVF as the positive poles, forming a vector that goes to the +60 degree mark. Finally, lead 3 uses aVL as negative and aVF as the positive pole, forming a vector that goes to the +120 degree mark 
In inferior wall myocardial infarction (MI), the inferior portion of the heart (that is usually supplied by the right coronary artery) is affected, which causes ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF.
 

Option Analysis

❌ ST-elevation in leads I, V5, and aVL  :
Incorrect: Leads I, V5, and aVL correspond to the lateral wall of the heart that is supplied by the left circumflex artery.  
❌ ST-elevation in leads V1 and V2:
Incorrect: ST-elevation in leads V1 and V2 would be seen in MI involving the septal wall of the heart that is usually supplied by the left anterior descending artery.  
❌ ST-elevation in leads V3 and V4  :
Incorrect: ST-elevation in leads V3 and V4 would be seen in MI involving the anterior wall of the heart that is usually supplied by the left anterior descending artery.  
✅ ST-elevation in leads II, III, and aVF:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ST-depression in leads I and V5:
Incorrect: Leads I, and V5 correspond to the lateral wall of the heart that is supplied by the left circumflex artery.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to his outpatient provider due to periorbital edema and lower extremity swelling. He has also experienced weight gain despite making no changes to his diet or exercise routine. Laboratory testing demonstrates proteinuria. An additional workup is performed and the patient is diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome. A change in which of the following factors is primarily responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome. In this condition, damage to the glomerular filtration barrier leads to massive proteinuria and loss of albumin (a major plasma protein). As a result, there is decreased capillary oncotic pressure and subsequent fluid extravasation into the interstitial space.

The net movement of water across capillaries is described using the Starling equation. The formula is as follows:

The equation states there are two types of forces acting within, and outside, the capillaries, that determine fluid movement. The capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc) pushes fluid out of the capillaries, whereas the interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi) pushes fluid into the capillaries. There are also osmotic pressures and these forces pull fluids in their direction. The capillary oncotic pressure (πc) pulls fluid into the capillaries, whereas the interstitial oncotic pressure (πi) pulls fluid into the interstitium.

The filtration coefficient (Kf) is not a force but instead determines the water permeability of the capillary walls. Lastly, there is the reflection coefficient (σ), which describes the capillary’s permeability to proteins. A coefficient of 1 means the capillary is impermeable to protein, whereas 0 means it is completely permeable.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Capillary hydrostatic pressure  :
Incorrect: This patient has nephrotic syndrome. The condition is characterized by the loss of albumin and other proteins via urine. These changes would result in a decreased capillary oncotic pressure, which in turn causes fluid extravasation from the capillaries into the interstitial space.  
❌ Interstitial hydrostatic pressure  :
Incorrect: This patient has nephrotic syndrome. The condition is characterized by the loss of albumin and other proteins via urine. These changes would result in a decreased capillary oncotic pressure, which in turn causes fluid extravasation from the capillaries into the interstitial space.  
✅ Capillary oncotic pressure  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Interstitial oncotic pressure  :
Incorrect: The interstitial oncotic pressure is determined by the protein concentration of the interstitial fluid and is usually quite low. Nephrotic syndrome primarily leads to the loss of albumin (a major plasma protein) via the urine, which leads to decreased capillary oncotic pressure.  
❌ Capillary permeability  :
Incorrect: Inflammatory conditions (e.g., infection, vasculitis) and burns can increase capillary permeability and enable more fluid to extravasate into the interstitial space. While some causes of nephrotic syndrome (e.g. membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis) are associated with inflammation, the primary cause of edema is nonetheless the proteinuria and subsequent decrease in capillary oncotic pressure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic to establish care. She has not seen a doctor in many years. She has no active complaints. Physical examination is unremarkable. Cardiac auscultation reveals a midsystolic click followed by a short late-systolic murmur at the cardiac apex. When the patient is asked to bear down against a closed glottis, it makes the click occur earlier in systole. Which of the following is the most likely cause of change in the timing of systolic click with this maneuver?

choices.text: Increased blood flow through an abnormal valve
Decrease in transaortic valve pressure gradient
Increased right ventricular filling and ejection time

questions.solution:
The auscultatory findings of midsystolic click followed by a short late-systolic murmur in this patient are typical for mitral valve prolapse. The murmur results from regurgitation of blood due to malaligned valve margins secondary to prolapse. The click is caused by the sudden tensing of the chordae tendineae as they are pulled tight by the ballooning valve leaflets.

In patients with MVP, there is a set left ventricular (LV) size during systole at which prolapse occurs. Therefore, maneuvers that change the LV end-diastolic volume affect the timing of the click and the murmur. Decreases in LV volume (e.g. secondary to decreased preload during the straining phase of Valsalva) reduce the tension and increase the slack in the mitral valve apparatus. Because the ventricular walls are closer, they reach the critical LV size earlier, leading to an earlier systolic click. The opposite is also true, i.e. increases in LV volume (e.g. secondary to increased preload during squatting) increase the distance between ventricular walls, thereby taking more time to reach the critical LV size, as a result of which prolapse occurs later in systole or not at all.  

Option Analysis

✅ Decrease in left ventricular volume:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased blood flow through an abnormal valve:
Incorrect: Murmurs that increase in intensity due to increased blood flow include murmurs produced due to stenotic and regurgitant valves (e.g. mitral regurgitation). The straining phase of Valsalva decreases preload, which reduces the flow through the valves.  
❌ Increased preload:
Incorrect: Murmurs that increase in intensity due to increased preload include murmurs produced due to stenotic and regurgitant valves (e.g. mitral regurgitation). The straining phase of Valsalva decreases preload.  
❌ Decrease in transaortic valve pressure gradient:
Incorrect: Decrease in transaortic valve pressure gradient due to maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g. handgrip) decreases the intensity of aortic stenosis murmur.  
❌ Increased right ventricular filling and ejection time:
Incorrect: Increased right ventricular filling and ejection time (as observed in conditions that increase preload like deep inspiration) leads to delay in closure of the pulmonic valve, which causes physiologic splitting of the second heart sound (S2). It decreases the intensity of the MVP murmur.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of intermittent palpitations. He denies any episodes of syncope, chest pain, shortness of breath, or vomiting. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed which is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of observed findings in this patient’s ECG?  
 

Reproduced from: Osmosis notes

choices.text: Slowing of conduction at the AV node

questions.solution:
This patient with palpitations and electrocardiogram (ECG) findings of irregularly irregular rhythm and absence of distinct P waves, most likely has new-onset atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is one of the most common cardiac arrhythmias. It is more prevalent in men and with increasing age. Risk factors include hypertensive heart disease, coronary artery disease, and rheumatic heart disease. AF has the following electrocardiographic characteristics:
  
  •  The RR intervals follow no repetitive pattern (irregularly irregular).  
  •  Absence of distinct P waves. Thus, even when an atrial cycle length (the interval between two atrial activations or the P-P interval) can be defined, it is not regular. 
Usually, it occurs when there are multiple ectopic foci in the atria that start firing all at once, the atrial rate can increase to 350-450 beats per minute. These foci fire too quickly for the atria to be fully depolarized by any one of them, so with AF, there aren’t any P-waves on an ECG; but, rather small waves that reflect waves of atrial depolarization that couldn’t make it through the AV node. The ventricular rate is much lower than the atrial rate, but still can be over 120 beats per minute.  


Option Analysis

✅ Ectopic foci in the atria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Slowing of conduction at the AV node  :
Incorrect: Slowing of conduction at the AV node usually results in a first-degree or Mobitz type I second-degree heart block in which the PR segment is prolonged. In contrast, no distinct P waves can be appreciated in this patient’s ECG.  
❌ Conduction block below AV node  :
Incorrect: A conduction block below the AV node usually leads to Mobitz Type II second-degree heart block which appears on the ECG as an abnormal PR segment with a beat drop. In contrast, no distinct P-waves can be appreciated in this patient’s ECG.  
❌ Conduction through an accessory pathway:
Incorrect: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome usually occurs as a result of an accessory conduction pathway (bundle of Kent) that results in pre-excitation and tachycardia. The classic ECG findings of WPW include a short PR interval and delta wave (slurred upstroke in the QRS complex) with or without nonspecific ST-T wave changes.  
❌ Defective myocardial sodium channels  :
Incorrect: Defective myocardial sodium channels are seen in patients with Brugada syndrome. The common ECG pattern seen in such patients includes ST elevation in leads V1 and V2 and predisposes to ventricular (not atrial) arrhythmias.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study on cardiac physiology. The test subject has a heart rate of H and an ejection fraction of F. The subject’s pressure-volume loop is shown below. Which of the following best approximates the cardiac work (also termed stroke work) performed by this patient’s heart?
questions.solution:
Cardiac work (also called stroke) is the work the heart performs during each beat. It can be calculated by multiplying the stroke volume by the mean aortic pressure. Cardiac work can also be approximated as the area within the pressure-volume loop. Therefore, the bigger the loop and the greater its area, the more work the heart does.  

In this vignette, the pressure-volume loop is roughly the shape of a rectangle. The area is the product of the width and height, mathematically represented as (V3-V1)*(P3-P1). The rectangle’s width corresponds to the difference between V3 and V1, whereas its height corresponds to the difference between P3 and P1.  

A related concept is cardiac minute work, which is how much work the heart performs over a minute. It can be calculated by multiplying the cardiac work by the number of beats per minute. In this vignette, the cardiac minute work is mathematically represented as (V3-V1)*(P3-P1)*H.  

Option Analysis

✅ (V3-V1)*(P3-P1):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ (V3-V1)*(P3-P1)*H:
Incorrect: Cardiac work is the work the heart performs during each beat. It can be approximated as the area of the pressure-volume loop. Multiplying the cardiac work by the heart rate (as in this answer choice) will yield minute work, the amount of work the heart performs in a minute.  
❌ (V3-V1)*(P3-P2):
Incorrect: Cardiac work is the work the heart performs during each beat. It can be approximated as the area of the pressure-volume loop, which can be mathematically represented as the product of the loop’s height (P3-P1) and width (V3-V1).  
❌ (V3-V1)*(P3-P2)*H:
Incorrect: Cardiac work is the work the heart performs during each beat. It can be approximated as the area of the pressure-volume loop, which can be mathematically represented as the product of the loop’s height (P3-P1) and width (V3-V1).  
❌ (V3*F)*(P3-P1)*H  :
Incorrect: Cardiac work is the work the heart performs during each beat. The loop’s height is the difference between P3 and P1, whereas the loop’s width corresponds to the stroke volume, equal to the end-diastolic volume (V3) multiplied by the ejection fraction. However, multiplying the cardiac work by the heart rate will yield minute work.

questions.text: A patient's current pressure-volume loop is shown below in red. His pressure-volume loop from five years ago is shown below in dark blue as a reference. Which clinical scenarios would best account for the changes between the two pressure-volume loops?
questions.solution:
This patient’s most recent pressure-volume loop demonstrates increased stroke volume and decreased end-diastolic volume. Among the answer choices, only dobutamine (an inotropic medication) administration would account for these changes.  

Pressure-volume loops characterize changes in left ventricular pressure and volume throughout the cardiac cycle. Changes in contractility, preload, and afterload can all affect the shape of the pressure-volume loop.    

Increased contractility (e.g., catecholamine release, dobutamine use) will cause the heart to contract more forcefully and increase ventricular pressure during systole. As a result, more blood is ejected from the left ventricle during systole, meaning stroke volume will increase, and end-systolic volume will decrease.    

An increase in afterload (e.g., aortic stenosis, system hypertension) will lead to impaired ventricular emptying. In turn, ventricular pressure will have to rise higher than usual during systole to push blood out of the heart. Likewise, the heart can pump less blood out due to the increase in afterload. Therefore, stroke volume will decrease, and end-systolic volume will increase.    

Finally, an increase in preload (e.g. increased blood volume) means more blood enters the left ventricle during diastole, which translates into a greater end-diastolic volume. There is also a greater stroke volume given the Frank-Starling relation, which states that the greater the end-diastolic volume, the greater the stroke volume ejected during systole.  



Option Analysis

❌ Aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis will lead to an increase in cardiac afterload and aortic resistance. As a result, ventricular pressure during systole must rise higher than usual to push blood out of the left ventricle. Moreover, due to the increase in afterload, the heart can pump less blood out of the heart. Therefore, aortic stenosis would lead to an increased end-systolic volume and decreased stroke volume, as seen in the graph below.  

❌ Systolic heart failure:
Incorrect: Systolic heart failure is characterized by a loss of inotropy, which prevents blood from being squeezed out from the heart and results in an increased end-systolic volume. There may also be an increase in end-diastolic volume since the condition causes blood to pool in the pulmonary and venous circulation, thereby increasing preload. A pressure-volume loop of this can be seen below. This patient’s most recent pressure-volume loop does not reflect these changes.  
 

❌ Recent blood transfusion:
Incorrect: A blood transfusion would increase the circulating blood volume and preload. As a result, there would be greater ventricular filling during diastole and a higher end-diastolic volume, as seen in the pressure-volume loop below. In contrast, the end-diastolic volume remains unchanged between this patient’s two pressure-volume loops.


❌ Recent diltiazem administration:
Incorrect: Diltiazem is a nondihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that will lead to decreased cardiac contractility. As a result, diltiazem administration will decrease (as opposed to increasing) stroke volume.
✅ Dobutamine administration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine checkup. She does not have any active complaints. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 40 years ago. She takes amlodipine, metformin, and insulin. Cardiac auscultation reveals a low-frequency heart sound at the end of diastole that is best heard at the cardiac apex. This patient most likely has which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The auscultatory findings in this patient demonstrate a low-frequency extra heart sound at the end of diastole, known as the fourth heart sound (S4). It is often heard in older adults due to an age-related decline in left ventricular compliance and is a benign finding in such cases. However, it can be pathological in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy or left ventricular hypertrophy following prolonged hypertension (as in this case). It is thought to occur from a surge of blood striking a stiff left ventricle due to right atrial contraction. It may also be heard in patients during the early stages of an acute myocardial infarction–this sound occurs when the blood hits the noncompliant and infarcted cardiac tissue.  

Notably, ventricular gallops (S3 and S4) are best heard with the stethoscope bell over the cardiac apex. At the same time, the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position (brings the heart closer to the chest wall) at end-expiration (decreases lung volume).

Option Analysis

❌ Aortic root dilation:
Incorrect: Aortic root dilation can be associated with aortic insufficiency, which causes a high-pitched early diastolic decrescendo murmur instead of an extra heart sound.
❌ Atrial septal defect:
Incorrect: An atrial septal defect produces a fixed splitting of the second heart sound at the start of diastole.
❌ Mitral valve prolapse:
Incorrect: Mitral valve prolapse is classically associated with a mid-systolic click followed by a mid-to-late systolic murmur. It does not produce a diastolic sound or murmur.
❌ Patent ductus arteriosus  :
Incorrect: Patent ductus arteriosus causes a continuous machine-like murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular area.
✅ Left ventricular hypertrophy   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 18 weeks of gestation, comes to the clinic for a routine visit. She does not have any active complaints at this time. Their medical history is noncontributory, and she only takes multivitamins. Cardiac auscultation shows a low-frequency diastolic heart sound that is heard shortly after the second heart sound when the patient lies in the left lateral decubitus. Which of the following labeled phases of the cardiac cycle does this heart sound correspond to?
questions.solution:
The graph below depicts various pressure and volume changes that correspond to the electromechanical activity of the heart with each heartbeat, called the cardiac cycle.  

A normal adult human heart makes two heart sounds during a typical cardiac cycle called the first (S1) and second, (S2) heart sounds. S1  is auscultated at the start of systole due to the closure of atrioventricular valves. At the same time, S2 is heard at the beginning of diastole due to the closure of the semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonic valves).  

In high output states (e.g., pregnancy, anemia) or patients with systolic heart failure, a third (S3) heart sound can also be heard. It is a low-frequency sound that occurs shortly after S2 during diastole. It is caused by the sudden limitation of ventricular movement during rapid passive ventricular filling. The fourth (S4) heart sound is an extra low-frequency heart sound that coincides with atrial contraction and is produced by the resultant surge of blood striking a stiff left ventricle. It can be heard in older adults secondary to an age-related decrease in ventricular compliance. Other pathologic causes included concentric hypertrophy and restrictive cardiomyopathy.  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This phase of the cardiac cycle corresponds to atrial depolarization. It causes atrial contraction that increases the atrial pressure and pumps blood into the ventricle. In patients with diastolic dysfunction, an abnormal gallop sound can be heard in this phase as blood is forced into the stiff ventricle, called S4.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the isovolumetric ventricular contraction phase in which a rise in ventricular pressure leads to closure of atrioventricular valves, making the first heart sound (S1). In this instance, the ventricles contract against closed valves leading to an abrupt rise in ventricular pressure. Once it exceeds the aortic pressure, the aortic valve opens.
❌ C:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the ventricular ejection phase of the cardiac cycle. It marks the opening of the aortic valve, which leads to the decline in the ventricular volume and pressure until it is lower than the aortic pressure, at which point the aortic valve closes back. No heart sounds are heard in this phase.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the isovolumetric ventricular relaxation phase that occurs during diastole and starts when the aortic valve closes due to declining ventricular pressure, producing a second heart sound (S2). The aortic valve closes before the pulmonic valve.  
✅ E:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: You are teaching the medical students how to measure jugular venous pressure at the bedside. A normal jugular venous pressure tracing is shown. Which of the following labels corresponds to the right atrial passive emptying phase?
questions.solution:
The jugular venous pressure (JVP) is the pressure over the internal jugular vein that can be visualized during physical examination. It gives an indirect estimate of right atrial pressure since it follows about the same pressure changes as those in the right atrium. During a normal cardiac cycle, the changes in the JVP can be noted, as shown in the image below.  

When the right atrium actively empties the residual blood, it can be seen on the JVP tracing as a wave. It is followed by a closure of the tricuspid valve and right ventricular contraction that causes bulging of the valve in the right atrium, which is projected as the c wave. Shortly after that, the pulmonic valve opens, causing rapid ejection of the blood from the right ventricle. This decreases right atrial pressure, which is noted as the x descent. At this point, the right atrium starts filling up again for the next cardiac cycle. This corresponds to the v wave, indicating rising atrial pressure. Finally, after ventricular emptying, the tricuspid valve opens again, causing ejection of blood into the right ventricle and rapid fall in right atrial pressure noted as the y descent. It is prominent in constrictive pericarditis and absent in cardiac tamponade.  



Option Analysis

❌ Label A:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the right atrial contraction after the right passive emptying phase. It empties the residual blood in the right atrium into the right ventricle. It is absent in atrial  fibrillation.  
❌ Label C:
Incorrect: This label corresponds to the abrupt rise in right atrial pressure secondary to right ventricular contraction against the closed tricuspid valve during the isovolumetric contraction phase.  
❌ Label X  :
Incorrect: This corresponds to atrial relaxation and downward displacement of the closed tricuspid valve during the rapid ventricular ejection phase. Since the tricuspid valve is closed, right atrial emptying does not occur in this phase. This phase can be reduced or even absent in patients with tricuspid regurgitation or right heart failure due to loss of pressure gradient.  
❌ Label V:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the rise in right atrial pressure due to increasing right atrial volume against the closed tricuspid valve. Right atrial emptying does not occur in this phase.  
✅ Label Y  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the clinic to establish care. He currently has no active complaints. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Cardiac auscultation reveals two heart sounds, one at the start of systole and corresponding to the pulse. The heart sound described in this patient occurs as a result of the following?

choices.text: Blood striking a stiff left ventricle

questions.solution:
A normal adult human heart makes two heart sounds during a typical cardiac cycle called the first (S1), and second, (S2) heart says. S1 is auscultated at the start of systole due to the closure of atrioventricular valves (mitral and tricuspid valves). At the same time, S2 is heard at the beginning of the diastole of the semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonic valves). S1 radiates to all cardiac listening posts but is loudest at the apex. S2 can be divided into A2 (aortic valve) and P2 (pulmonic valve). A2 is loudest at the right upper sternal border, while P2 is at the left upper sternal border.  

Option Analysis

❌ Blood striking a stiff left ventricle:
Incorrect: S4 is a low-frequency extra heart sound at the end-diastole that occurs from a surge of blood striking a stiff left ventricle during right-atrial contraction. Causes include an age-related decline in ventricular compliance, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and left ventricular hypertrophy.
❌ Rapid passive filling of ventricles  :
Incorrect: Third heart sound (S3) is caused by a sudden limitation of ventricular movement during the rapid passive ventricular filling phase. Its presence in patients aged >40 suggests ventricular volume overload that can be secondary to aortic/mitral regurgitation or systolic heart failure.  
✅ Closure of mitral valve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Closure of aortic valve  :
Incorrect: Closure of the aortic valve produces a second heart (S2) sound that occurs during diastole when the aortic valve closes due to declining ventricular pressure in the isovolumetric ventricular relaxation phase.  
❌ Aortic root dilation  :
Incorrect: Aortic root dilation can be associated with aortic insufficiency, which produces a high-pitched early diastolic decrescendo murmur instead of an extra heart sound.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department with shortness of breath. He uses 3-pillows at night to help relieve his dyspnea. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and inferior wall myocardial infarction treated medically a year ago. Cardiac auscultation reveals a low-frequency diastolic sound that is heard at the cardiac apex shortly after the sound of closure of the aortic valve. An echocardiogram shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30-35%. Which of the following is the most likely heart sound described in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with dyspnea and orthopnea, together with echocardiographic finding of ejection fraction of 30-35%, most likely has acute decompensation of systolic heart failure (now referred to as heart failure with reduced ejection fraction [HFrEF]). Cardiac examination reveals a low-frequency sound heard shortly after S2 during diastole, the third heart sound (S3).  

A third heart sound (S3) is caused by a sudden limitation of ventricular movement during the cardiac cycle's rapid passive ventricular filling phase. It can be a normal finding in healthy children, young adults, and pregnant women. However, patients aged >40 suggest ventricular volume overload that can be secondary to aortic/mitral regurgitation or systolic heart failure.  

Of note, ventricular gallops (S3 and S4) are best heard with the bell of the stethoscope over the cardiac apex. At the same time, the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position (brings the heart closer to the chest wall) at end-expiration (decreases lung volume).

Option Analysis

❌ S1:
Incorrect: The first heart sound (S1) occurs due to the closure of the atrioventricular valves (mitral and tricuspid valves) due to rising ventricular pressure in the isovolumetric ventricular contraction phase of the cardiac cycle.
❌ S2:
Incorrect: The second heart sound (S2) occurs due to the closure of the semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonic valves) due to declining ventricular in the isovolumetric ventricular relaxation phase of the cardiac cycle.
✅ S3:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ S4:
Incorrect: The fourth heart sound (S4) is an abnormal gallop sound that is heard in patients with diastolic dysfunction during the phase of atrial contraction. It occurs as a result of blood striking a stiff ventricle.
❌ A murmur of aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis usually causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur that is best heard in the right second intercostal space (aortic area).

questions.text: A researcher is studying the electromechanical activity of the heart throughout a normal cardiac cycle. Which of the following labels corresponds to the isovolumetric ventricular relaxation phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
The graph below depicts the pressure changes that correspond to the electromechanical activity of the heart with each heartbeat, called the cardiac cycle. The changes in the curves allow one to identify the cycle phases and the time of opening and closing of the cardiac valves.  

Isovolumetric ventricular relaxation is a phase that occurs during diastole and starts when the aortic valve closes due to declining ventricular pressure. During this phase, mitral and aortic valves are closed, causing an abrupt decline in ventricular pressure. When it becomes lower than the atrial pressure, the mitral valve opens, and the rapid ventricular filling phase starts.  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the isovolumetric ventricular contraction phase, in which a rise in ventricular pressure leads to the closure of atrioventricular valves. In this instance, the ventricles contract against closed valves leading to an abrupt increase in ventricular pressure. Once it exceeds the aortic pressure, the aortic valve opens.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the ventricular ejection phase of the cardiac cycle. It marks the opening of the aortic valve, leading to the ventricular volume and pressure decline until it is lower than the aortic pressure. At this point, the aortic valve closes back.
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: This corresponds to the rapid ventricular filling phase. It occurs when the atrial pressure exceeds the ventricular pressure, the two atrioventricular valves open, and the two ventricles start to fill rapidly with blood from the atria. This leads to a rapid fall in atrial pressure.  
❌ E  :
Incorrect: This is the first phase of the cardiac cycle as it corresponds to the atrial depolarization seen on an electrocardiogram as a P wave. It causes atrial contraction that increases the atrial pressure and pumps blood into the ventricle. As a result, the ventricular pressure slightly increases.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study on cardiac physiology. The study data is used to generate the left ventricular pressure-volume loop shown below. Which of the following best describes the cardiac cycle phase of each side of the loop?
questions.solution:
Pressure-volume loops characterize changes in left ventricular pressure (y-axis) and volume (x-axis) during the cardiac cycle. The loop can be divided into four phases: isovolumetric contraction, systolic ejection, isovolumetric relaxation, and ventricular filling.    

The right lower corner of the loop corresponds to the end-diastolic point. The mitral valve then closes, and the heart begins contracting, marking the beginning of systole. As the ventricle contracts, intraventricular pressure increases. However, since the mitral and aortic valves are closed, the blood has nowhere to go, and ventricular volume is unchanged. As a result, this phase (phase 1) is termed isovolumetric contraction.    

Eventually, intraventricular pressure exceeds the aortic pressure, forcing the aortic valve to open. Blood can now leave the left ventricle, and ventricular volume decreases. These physiological changes are represented by the loop's upper margin (phase 2) and systolic ejection.    

Eventually, aortic pressure exceeds left ventricular pressure, and the aortic valve closes, marking the end of systole. The ventricle begins relaxing, and intraventricular pressure decreases. Since the aortic valve is closed and the mitral valve has not yet opened, blood volume within the ventricle is unchanged. Hence, this phase (phase 3) is termed isovolumetric relaxation.    

Finally, the pressure within the left ventricle drops below the left atrium, enabling the mitral valve to open. Blood flows from the atrium into the ventricle, and its volume increases. This phase (phase 4) is termed ventricular filling. Once there is no more pressure gradient between the two chambers and the mitral valve closes, the cardiac cycle starts again.



Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: Phase 1 is characterized by an increase in ventricular pressure but no change in ventricular volume, which corresponds to isovolumetric contraction. Phase 2 is characterized by a decrease in ventricular volume and represents systolic ejection. Phase 3 is characterized by decreased ventricular pressure and means isovolumetric relaxation. Finally, phase 4 is characterized by increased ventricular volume and corresponds to ventricular filling.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Phases 1 and 2 correspond to isovolumetric contraction and systolic ejection. However, phase 3 represents isovolumetric relaxation. Ventricular filling, characterized by a progressive increase in ventricular volume, does not occur until phase 4.
❌ :
Incorrect: Phase 1 is characterized by an increase in ventricular pressure but no change in ventricular volume, corresponding to isovolumetric contraction. Phase 2 is characterized by a decrease in ventricular volume and represents systolic ejection. Phase 3 is characterized by decreased ventricular pressure and means isovolumetric relaxation. Finally, phase 4 is characterized by increased ventricular volume and corresponds to ventricular filling.
❌ :
Incorrect: During the ejection phase, blood leaves the right ventricle, and as a result, ventricular volume decreases. Phase 1 is characterized by an increase in ventricular pressure but no change in volume. Therefore, it cannot represent the ejection phase. In contrast, the ejection phase (both rapid and reduced ejection) occurs during phase 2.

questions.text: A physiologist is conducting a study on a human subject. The left ventricular pressure-volume loop below is generated using data obtained from the subject. The subject has a heart rate of H and ejection fraction of F. Which of the following best approximates the subject’s stroke volume?
questions.solution:
Pressure-volume loops characterize left ventricular pressure and volume changes during the cardiac cycle. Stroke volume can be calculated by finding the difference between the end-diastolic and end-systolic volumes.    

The right lower corner of the loop corresponds to the end-diastolic point. The blood volume in the ventricle is termed the end-diastolic volume (V3). The mitral valve then closes, and the heart begins contracting, marking the beginning of systole. As the ventricle contracts, intraventricular pressure increases.    

Eventually, intraventricular pressure exceeds the aortic pressure, forcing the aortic valve to open. Blood then leaves the left ventricle, causing ventricular volume and pressure to decrease progressively. When the aortic pressure exceeds the left ventricular pressure, the aortic valve closes, and the volume of blood remaining in the ventricle is termed the end-systolic volume (V1).
   
Stroke volume is the amount of blood ejected by the left ventricle during each systolic contraction. Therefore, it can be calculated by either finding the difference between the end-diastolic and end-systolic volumes (V3-V1), which is the loop’s width or by multiplying the end-diastolic volume by the ejection fraction (V3*F).  



Option Analysis

❌ (V3-V1)*(P4-P1)  :
Incorrect: Stroke work is the work the heart performs during each beat. It can be approximated as the area of the pressure-volume loop. If the loop is estimated to be a rectangle, the area is its width (V3-V1) multiplied by its height (P4-P1). However, this question asks for the stroke volume, not cardiac work.
❌ (V3-V1)*(P3-P1)*H  :
Incorrect: Minute work is the heart's amount of work in a minute. It can be calculated by multiplying stroke work ((V3-V1)*(P4-P1)), which can be approximated as the area of the pressure-volume loop, by the heart rate (H). However, this question asks for the stroke volume, not cardiac work.  
❌ (V3-V1)*F  :
Incorrect: Stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped out of the left ventricle during each heartbeat. It can be calculated by finding the difference between the end-diastolic volume (V3) and end-systolic volume (V1). Alternatively, it can be calculated by multiplying the end-diastolic volume by the ejection fraction. However, multiplying the stroke volume by the ejection fraction, as in this answer choice, will not yield a clinically-relevant value.  
❌ (P4-P3):
Incorrect: In the above diagram, P4 corresponds to the systolic blood pressure, whereas P3 corresponds to the diastolic blood pressure. The difference between P4 and P3 represents the pulse pressure, not the stroke volume.  
✅ (V3-V1)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department for the evaluation of syncope. Physical examination shows weak and slow rising arterial pulse. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh midsystolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space. Splitting of the second heart sound (S2) is also appreciated. Which of the following maneuvers will most likely eliminate the splitting of the second heart sound?
questions.solution:
This patient with pulsus parvus et tardus (weak and slow rising pulse) and auscultation finding of a harsh midsystolic murmur in the aortic area most likely has aortic stenosis (AS). AS can cause paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound (S2) that can be eliminated by deep inspiration.  

Physiologically, the second heart sound (S2) produced by the closure of aortic and pulmonic valves can be separated into A2 and P2. This is because the aortic valve usually closes before the pulmonic valve. This phenomenon can be augmented by inspiration, thereby increasing the venous return, leading to delayed closure of the pulmonic valve. Widening of this splitting can be in conditions that delay RV emptying.  

Paradoxical splitting is heard in conditions that delay aortic valve closure (e.g. aortic stenosis), due to which P2 occurs before A2. On inspiration, P2 closes later and moves closer to A2, “paradoxically” eliminating the split.  


Option Analysis

✅ Deep inspiration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amyl nitrate inhalation  :
Incorrect: Amyl nitrate causes vasodilation, resulting in a transient decrease in venous return. This would result in decreased right ventricular filling time and early closure of the pulmonic valve, potentiating the paradoxical splitting.
❌ Having the patient stand up:
Incorrect: Abrupt standing results in a transient decrease in venous return. This would decrease right ventricular filling time and lead to the earlier closure of the pulmonic valve, thereby potentiating the paradoxical splitting.
❌ Phase 2 of the Valsalva maneuver:
Incorrect: Phase 2 of the Valsalva maneuver (bearing down against a closed glottis) would decrease the venous return, potentiating the paradoxical splitting.

questions.text: An electrophysiologist is teaching medical students different aspects of a normal electrocardiogram with the cardiac cycle. Considering the following image to be a reading from limb lead II of an ECG, which of the following letters in the labeled image represents ventricular repolarization?
questions.solution:
In a healthy heart, the depolarization wave starts at the sinoatrial (SA) node in the right atrium from where it travels to the cardiac apex, which aligns with the lead II vector. It quickly travels through the intranodal tracts to the left atrium, causing a positive deflection on the electrocardiogram (ECG), called the P-wave. The wave is then carried to the AV node, where it gets delayed for a bit to allow the atria enough time to get fully emptied. It appears as a flat line on the ECG called the PR interval. From there, the signal goes through the pacemaker cells of the Bundle of His, and the bundle branches down into the Purkinje fibers. The apex of the heart depolarizes, followed by depolarization of the base, creating a QRS complex on the ECG.  

After tissue depolarizes, there is a brief absence of electrical activity, making an isoelectric line called the ST segment. After that, the ventricles repolarize, the wave of which travels in an overall upward direction. This appears on the ECG as a positive deflection called the T-wave, because it is a repolarization wave traveling towards a negative electrode.  

Option Analysis

❌ P:
Incorrect: This represents the P wave, which is a result of the beginning of the atrial depolarization wave that starts at the sinoatrial (SA) node in the right atrium and quickly travels to the left atrium through intranodal tracts. The direction is the same as that of the lead II vector, making the deflection positive.   
❌ Q:
Incorrect: From the AV node, the signal goes through the pacemaker cells of the Bundle of His and bundle branches. In addition to moving through the fast pacemaker cells, the signal also goes through the slow myocytes in the interventricular septum, in a direction that’s slightly away from the lead II vector, creating a tiny negative deflection on the ECG–a Q wave.  
❌ R:
Incorrect: When the depolarization wave flows down into the Purkinje fibers, the largest vectors are the ones in the left ventricle, in the direction of lead II, creating a large positive deflection on the ECG–an R wave.  
❌ S:
Incorrect: When the depolarization wave reaches the left ventricle, the apex of the heart depolarizes first. Then the wave moves back up to depolarize the top of the ventricles, which is in a direction away from lead II, causing a slight negative deflection on the ECG - an S wave.  
✅ T:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the cardiologist for evaluation of dyspnea and intermittent chest pain. An echocardiogram is performed as part of the workup and reveals aortic stenosis secondary to a bicuspid aortic valve. Which of the following best illustrates this patient’s left ventricular pressure-volume loop (red line) compared to that of a healthy individual of the same age (dark blue line)?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with aortic stenosis. The condition will increase cardiac afterload and manifest with changes to the pressure-volume loop, including an increase in systolic blood pressure and a decrease in stroke volume.  

Pressure-volume loops characterize changes in left ventricular pressure and volume throughout the cardiac cycle. The loop can be divided into four phases: isovolumetric contraction, systolic ejection, isovolumetric relaxation, and ventricular filling. The loop’s width corresponds to the stroke volume, which is the difference between the end-diastolic and end-systolic volumes.    

An increase in afterload (e.g., aortic stenosis, system hypertension) will lead to impaired ventricular emptying. In aortic stenosis, aortic resistance increases, and the ventricular pressure during systole has to rise higher than usual for blood to be pushed out into the aorta. Hence, the height of the pressure-volume loop will increase. Furthermore, an increase in afterload means less blood can be pumped out of the heart during each beat. As a result, the end-systolic volume will be higher than that of a healthy individual, and stroke volume will decrease, which manifests as a narrowing of the pressure-volume loop.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: These changes may occur in individuals with systolic heart failure. The condition is characterized by a loss of inotropy, which prevents blood from being squeezed out of the heart and results in an increased end-systolic volume. There may also be an increase in end-diastolic volume since the condition causes blood to pool within the pulmonary and venous circulation, thereby increasing preload.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: Increased cardiac contractility (e.g., sympathetic stimulation, digoxin administration) would result in this pressure-volume loop. Increased cardiac contractility means the heart beats more forcefully, and more blood is ejected from the left ventricle during systole. As a result, stroke volume will increase, and end-systolic volume will decrease.
❌ :
Incorrect: An increase in preload would result in greater ventricular filling and a greater end-diastolic volume. In contrast, aortic stenosis would lead to an increase in afterload.
❌ :
Incorrect: Mitral stenosis would result in this pressure-volume loop. Mitral stenosis impairs ventricular filling and leads to a decrease in end-diastolic volume. As a result, there is a decrease in stroke volume by the Frank-Starling relationship and a fall in cardiac output and aortic pressure. This reduction in afterload enables the end-systolic volume to decrease slightly (but not enough to overcome the decrease in end-diastolic volume).

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents for evaluation of fatigue and dyspnea. These symptoms are exacerbated by exertion. She immigrated from Cambodia 15 years ago. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies and an episode of severe pharyngitis as a child. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 127/81 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. On physical examination, an opening snap is heard after the S2 heart sound. This murmur is best heard over the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Pulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. This patient will most likely have which of the following pressure-volume loops?  

*The dark blue loop represents that of a healthy individual and is meant to serve as a reference.
questions.solution:
This patient has a remote history of pharyngitis and currently presents with a cardiac murmur best heard over the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. These findings are suggestive of mitral stenosis. The pressure-volume changes associated with mitral stenosis, along with other valvular disorders, can be found in the below table:  



Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has a history of pharyngitis as a child and currently presents with a cardiac murmur best heard over the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line.
